Rev. Canon H.G. Cook, D.D.,
102 Bank Street,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Canon Cook:

Miss Katherine Gull - Waswanipi Band

We have a suggestion from Bishop Benson that this girl be assisted to train as a nurse or teacher.

It is suggested that this girl be sent to Moose Factory for a year's apprenticeship to be served in your hospital and residential school. If at the end of that time she shows the necessary progress, aptitude, and interest she will be considered for employment in the Government hospital there. As far as teaching is concerned it has yet to be demonstrated that Miss Gull's abilities lie in this field and she should not be entrusted with the usual duties of a teacher in a residential school.

The suggested arrangement between your administration and this Department is that you should provide room and board and training under qualified instructors and the Department will pay the girl's transportation from Waswanipi to Moose Factory and return and the sum of $30 a month to the hospital patron of which she shall pay to the girl $10 a month as pocket money. The monthly payments are to be claimed quarterly through our Superintendent at Aosee, Que. The agreement may be terminated by either party after a month's notice.

We are writing to the girl to determine whether she will accept this offer of room and board, training, and $10 a month.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Shelton,
Chief, Education Division.
September 16, 1949.

Mr. H. Lariviere,
Supt. of Indian Agency,
Amos, Que.

Katherine Gull - Waswanipi Band

Enclosed is a copy of the letter to this Indian girl.

When you receive from her the answer that she is prepared to accept the proposal which is made in this letter, please make arrangements for her to proceed to Moose Factory.

There is, of course no guarantee that this experiment will be successful. A year from now the girl may not wish to continue at Moose Factory, but if she returns to our service at Waswanipi she will be better equipped to work there.

This arrangement is being made in accordance with the view that any Indians who are to be employed as assistants to nurses or teachers require more schooling and directed training.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.
October 6th, 1949

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Your No. 42074-3 (E1)

October 6th, 1949

Re: Miss. Kathleen Gull, attached hereto copy of letter to Miss. Gull, which speaks for itself.

I doubt letter will reach her now, before late December or later.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian Agency
October 13th, 1948

To Miss. Kathleen Gull (Katherine)
Wassanipi Post,
c/o Hudson's Bay Company,
via Bennetboro, Que.

Please forward to Wassanipi lst. mail: (cover marked)

Dear Miss. Gull,

I regret to say it is impossible for the Department to allow you, more than $10.00 per month, for class of work - training at an hospital or equal.

The offer, is the same as for the other girls, now at La Tigue.

Let me know by first mail, if you accept or not. The $10.0 allowance, is for your sundry needs; you get your board, living free, as at La Tigue.

Yours very truly,

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian Agency.

DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES
INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH

October 20th, 1949

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Your letter No. 42074-3 (E1) August 5th, and telegram dated August 10th, 1949

I now submit the following forms covering our final admissions on this training plan - Nurses Aid - Field.

1. Charlotte Gull - Waswanipi - 3rd year.
2. Delina Plamand - Manawan - 2nd year.
3. Flora Gull - Waswanipi - 1st year.
4. Jeannie Neepoosh - Mistassini - last year.

Rose Salome - Obedjiwan - Test only for suitability

I am extremely pleased to report that the hospital has advised that particularly Indian girl Flora Gull shows signs that she will be outstanding, already picking-up some English and French and well liked by all.

Outside of above, the hospital has hired Miss. Annie Duke from Manawan and Miss. Charlotte Blacksmith from Waswanipi, on their regular staff, both were on training last year, both not good enough for our purposes, however the Sisters claimed under their guidance, they consider them valuable maids, the girls accepted their offer for employment. By next season we might be able to get a number of girls willing to go out and work at hospital work, this more so at Waswanipi.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian Agency.

Department of Indian Affairs

Blood

Tuition
Mr. Cough,
Indian Agent:
Dear Sir:

After our conversation of April 11th, in regards to the education of our boys. My husband and I have talked and thought over everything most conscientiously, looking at it from all angles. We have come to the conclusion that we would rather send our children to the day school in Cardston, Building on the Reserve, adjacent to the school. It will not interfere with my husband working the farm. Please be good enough to take it up with the Department of Indian Affairs for me. The Dept. is doing its best to educate and civilize us. We have done our utmost to profit by what teaching we have received.

As a mother, I feel that I am capable of raising my children up.
in a clean healthy home environment, which is so essential to the molding of their characters, enabling them to take their places in the world as useful men and women. We have outlived the state of depending on others to raise our children for us. Furthermore we are not asking the Dept. for any grant for the boys. Whereby their consent to send them to the day school realizing it is to be entirely at our own expense. Trusting you will do what is best in the matter.

I am,

Yours Truly,
Ethel Phil Feathers
Blood Indian Reserve,
Cardston, Alta.
Aug 16th 1938.

The Minister of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;-

To whom it may concern,

I feel at liberty to ask a request of you, that is, may I be permitted to have my boy of six yrs. old go to school in town here at Cardston day school.

My reasons are, we live right next to town, and thought would be very convenient for a little child of six to go to a day school than to a boarding or Residential school.

Our medical Doctor for the Indians on the Reserve estimated that there are 350 cases of tuberculosis and eye diseases.
in those two Residential schools on the Blood Indian Reservation, therefore it is not safe to put a little child in.

It is in these schools that these contagious diseases spread. A child five or six years old cannot look after her or himself and don't get the necessary food such as eggs, butter, & milk sufficiently to grow strong. And also there is too much confinement in a boarding school.

My aim is to maintain the good health of my child and get good education.

Trusting and hoping my sincere desire would be fulfilled promptly before the schools start again.

I would promise to stand all necessary expenses, without
your aid.

I am yours very sincerely,

Mrs. Emil Small Face.
Blood Agency,
Cardston,
Aug. 26th

Mr. Pugh,
Indian Agent:
Dear Sir:

Kindly forgive my imposing on your time and attention in this manner; my reason for doing so I may state as follows:— After reading Mr. Hoey's circular, stating that all residents of Indian schools are to be deprived of any holiday, other than the two months in the summer, I beg of you to be good enough to look it up with Mr. Hoey for me, asking for the privilege of sending my
boys to St. Paul's Anglican School, as day pupils. I would like to remind you what you took it up with the Dept. before for me, and there was no objection. I thought that still stood good. And have been sending my boys for the day since! You know we live close to the school, and they are always on time.

It has always been the aim of the Indian Dept. to educate us and encourage each one to have homes of their own, and be capable of bettering our living conditions. I feel that some of us have realized that state of depending on the Dept. and Church to look after our children. We are prepared to shoulder the expense of educating
feeding and clothing our children. There by having the Govt. grant for some one else.

There are exceptions to every rule, and Mr. Pugh I don't feel I am asking for anything out-of-the-way. I want to raise my children in a good home atmosphere, which is so essential to the moulding of their characters. Furthermore I want to give my boys the encouragement I feel so important to their art. Mr. Holy has already seen not Gerald's work. If they had been home with me, that talent would never have been developed. As you know I had a very hard time getting lessons for them, and had to make head work to sell, to keep them...
They do not have any chance of practicing their art at school.

An Indian's Part in the War

By ALLEN TAIL FEATHERS.

One of the educational projects recently undertaken by the Jane Macary Chapter, I.O.D.E., was a prize offered to the student who would write an essay for the School on the Blood Reserve for an essay on an Indian's part in the war. The contest was named for Miss Jane Macary, so closely connected with St. Paul's Indian School.

First prize in the contest was a $50 W.W.II Victory Bond, which was won by Allen Tail Feathers, aged 14 years, Grade 9, Dorchester School, 14 years old, in Grade 8, and was given to Chief Moon.

On Sept. 16, 1877, near Calgary, on the Blood Reserve, a treaty was in progress. You will wonder what it all about. It was between the Canadian government and the Blackfoot tribe. It was a treaty to banish all warfare between the Indians and the white men were to help them in every way. This treaty was signed by Chief Moon on Sept. 22, 1877.

Then came September, 1938, the world was rudely awakened with the stunning news that war was once again in progress. Adolf Hitler, the dictator, had broken his promises and started another war because of it. He broke all promises and marched into Poland, which became Britain's ally. France declared war.

Every Canadian knew that it was a grave hour of danger, so they immediately started to launch Victory drives, and buy Victory Loans, Victory Bonds and War Savings Certificates.

Now that the British Empire is in a critical position, even Canada has realized its duty to help win this war. Those who cannot go overseas are doing their bit in their own little way. How? By donating all they can to the Red Cross, War Savings Certificates, Bonds and War Savings Certificates, buying Victory Loans, luxuries and sacrificing some of the necessary articles that may serve by buying every scrap of rubber, tin, iron and paper.

Here comes the time when Indian comes in. The Indians of the Dominion of Canada are doing everything possible to help win this war. They do not want to be seen as a separate race or a nationality. Many Indians, all over the Dominion, have joined and answered the Canadian Army Overseas. The women are trying to get in the women's army. From the Blood Reserve, Cardston, 12 boys have volunteered for the army. Four are now in the Officer Cadet Corps, four more in the first line defence of Britain. Many more have enlisted from other Indian Reserves in Canada.

At the same Blood Reserve, the children are doing their part, and as a result of this, two hundred dollars from the community funds were given to help buy munitions so vital to Britain's great cause. These Indians are doing willingly, sensing the danger of subjugation by the Axis Powers, if they do their part.

Another incident brings us to Nelson, B.C., where there are 1,000 Indians. They do not live on a Reserve but represent the residential movement. These Indians decided they would support their relief agency, the Red Cross, by selling stamps, under a ruthless dictator.

There are Indians working in factories, air plants, munition plants and lumber camps. These Indians, however, are very anxious, dreading the possibility of domination by the Japanese, who are now coming down the B.C. coast.

The Indians are collecting money for help towards the soldiers now fighting for their lives. On the Blood Reserve they collect money by having dances and sports. They are also buying stamps towards buying cigarettes for the Indians in the Army from St. Paul's school.

The women on the Reserves are sewing clothes, knitting garments for the people in Britain, who are being bombed and starved and having all their belongings ruined. There are many Indian women's societies, which, in turn, are helping the Red Cross.

There are many more incidents taking place all over the Dominion. The Indians of North America have always been loyal to the British Crown during the pioneer days and are proving it in these trying times.

Let us realize that it is our duty to help, by enlisting, by buying stamps, by buying salvage, so that the Axis powers, who are killing our lives, the lives of every decent nation, with subjugation and dictatorship, will

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Reference No. 103-103

I appreciate very much your kindness in writing with regard to G.T. Fethers. Have discussed the whole question with Mr. McMillan.

I have the same reaction to these cases as yourself, and for that reason have long since ceased to pass on recommendations wherever there was an issue of doubt.

Gerald is an exception to the general rule. Basically, he is an artist -- not one of the "Slap-dash" variety, but temperamentally ranks far higher than the average.

He has gained for himself many friends in and around the Art Schools he has attended, and all the Instructors remark about his native and acquired talent towards a successful career.

There is no danger of his "returning to the Blankets" idea. He is too fastidious in personality. I mean by that, his whole outlook on life is essentially "White." His mother, (a very forceful character for good), was the best educated person amongst the Bloods, and she left an indelible impression for ambition in her children.

I would say, with utter candour, that any interest, financial or otherwise, expended on Gerald at the present juncture, will ultimately rebound to the public at large.
The Principal of the Technical Institute, also two of the Faculty, assured me last Spring that if Gerald could have one more year's tuition, he would be qualified for any position in the realm of Art, commercial or otherwise.

It has been his desire and ambition for years past to qualify as an artist, chiefly because of his natural ability and general outlook. His health is the best possible.

I would strongly recommend that the Grant be continued in his favour for the School Year 1942-43.

In order to convey to you a more comprehensive picture of the family, I have attached, herewith, an Essay written by Gerald's younger brother now here in School. A leading Barrister in Lethbridge acted as examiner of the Essays, and awarded the prizes accordingly. Much interest has been aroused by the excellence of the article. Feel sure you will be interested to read it.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Allan came to the Crescent Heights High School as a student on probation. Coming from an Indian School, he naturally had no certificates for Junior High School leaving. His training was defective in Mathematics, Science, and Languages as basic work in these subjects is given in the Junior High School Program (Grades 7,8,9).

At my request the Department of Education granted him probationary standing in English, Social Studies, Health and P.E., Art, and General Shop of the first year of the Senior High School Program. These were confirmed at the end of his first year of Crescent Heights on the basis of work done in that year, 1944-45.

In 1944-45 Allan passed the maximum number of credits allowed by the Department of Education. The Alberta system does not permit a student to take 2 sciences or 2 mathematics in this year. He was able therefore to take English, Social Studies, Health, Physical Ed., and Art of the second year high school course but was still required to take 1 science, 1 math, and 1 language of the first year. This put him a year behind in those subjects.

In 1945-46 he was able to take third year English, Social Studies, and Algebra and Chemistry. He was required to take a second year math, Geometry 1 which is a prerequisite to Trig. He failed in Chemistry and repeated it in 1946-47.

In 1946-47 he still had to complete his Matriculation by completing Trig, Physics 2, Latin 3 and Chemistry 2.

Alberta does not recognize any such standing as Junior Matriculation, as does B.C., but compels all students to complete 3 years of Senior High School. Alberta does not recognize a one-year Teacher Training Course except the emergency course necessary during the war when the shortage of teachers became acute. A temporary one year course is given the successful completion of which allows a person to teach for two years in a one-room school, with grades not exceeding grade 6. Students above that grade must take the correspondence course for grades 7 or 8, provided by the Department under supervision of the head teacher. Grade 9 is not permitted. This permit must be enlarged upon by attendance at two summer schools to permit the teacher to continue. The course is therefore valueless, as it lapses after 2 years.

There is a two-year course giving license to teach up to and including grades 8, 9, and 9, provided that the holder enlarges his certificate by attendance at summer schools. He must also take certificates of competency in the various optional subjects required by the Junior High School program (grades 7,8,9) in such subjects as Shop, Drama, Typing, Music and Art, and French. These certificates alone will require two summer schools.

A 3-year course leading to a B.A. is provided by the University of Alberta. This also requires extension and enlargement for the optional subjects of the Senior High School program, much the same as those of the Junior High School program outlined above, but including P.T.

A 4-year course leading to the degree of B.A., B. Educ. is provided by the University of Alberta. This qualifies the holder to teach any subject in any grade and implies specialists training. This is the only course worth taking if one intends to teach, and this is that we wish Allan to take.

Teaching in one of the present Indian Schools is hardly an objective. The salary paid does not permit any saving and extremely poor training because of the half time system. The city of Calgary for example does not recognize as experience, time spent in an Indian school and will not employ such a teacher. (I can give examples)

Discrimination in the matter of salary is evident on the basis of training. A perusal of the Teachers Wanted advertisements will illustrate my point. The city of Calgary also requires two degrees to reach the possible salary maximum.

Allan should be definitely trained to teach in the white schools or to take a Principal's job over a 4 or 5 room Indian Day school if he is to reach anything like a living wage.
ALBERTA SYSTEM:

Junior Grades 1-3
Intermediate 4-6
Junior High 7-9 (Public School Leaving or High School Entrance)
Senior High 10-12

No Junior Matriculation or Normal Entrance any more at end of Grade XI

Honor Matric (Ontario)

Harold Healy is a young blood Indian, who has shown considerable ability to do leathercraft work. During the past summer he saved sufficient harvest wages to pay for a course in leathercraft at the Alberta Institute of Technology and Art, Calgary. We were able to place him with the Great West Saddlery of Calgary, where he is serving an apprenticeship, and at the same time receiving night school instruction at the Tech.

This barely covers his board and room, clothing and incidentals, and he has no money with which to purchase the tools needed in his work.

I am attaching a list of these tools. The prices quoted are subject to fluctuation, but the company will supply them at their laid down cost. It should be pointed out that the company does not supply tools to its workers. Most of them are employed on piece work and must supply their own tools just as a carpenter must supply his. They are imported from the United States, and unlike the amount asked for now in Canada, it is possible that they might run a few dollars in excess of this amount.

Harold will likely require more tools later, but it is felt that if we can supply these now, he will soon be in a position where he will be earning more and he should be able to purchase his own tools then.

I wish to recommend that this expenditure be made, and that we be advised as soon as possible as Harold has reached the stage where he cannot go on with some of the more intricate designs.

EDITORIAL

With the enrolment this week of four young Indian students in our High School, another chapter of progress and advancement has been started. For a number of years efforts of a sort have been made to give these pupils the benefits and advantages of academic courses which our High School has to offer, but previously, something has always seemed to intervene to gum up negotiations and halt any real forward move. Apparently now the local and St. Mary's School Board, and the agencies that have to do with the Indians, have reached an amicable settlement and decision of all problems and the four young people, two young ladies, and two young men, are embarking on the path to higher and specialized education.

We feel that congratulations are due all around, that this achievement has been made. The local Board, under the Chairmanship of Art Landrigan, and the large Divisional Board, represented locally by John S. Smith, have made a real step forward. It would be too bad indeed not to share our facilities and advantages with our neighbors. The Indian population cannot justify a complete High School education, and in making our facilities available to the Indian students who desire to carry on in learning, we feel that a big step toward better understanding, greater confidence and closer friendship has been made.

Too much cannot be said too, of the benefits of the two schools on the Reserve—St. Paul's and St. Mary's—for the fundamental training and teaching given to the Indian children, and we hope that as the students from the reserve come into our schools, that they will come with the encouragement and the benediction of their former teachers, who better than any others, understand and appreciate the true values of education in the life of individuals and nations.

When these children finish their schooling, specialize for teachers in Agriculture, Manual Training, Domestic Science and the many other branches of specialized learning, there should be an invitation for them to return to their own people and through the use of this learning, enrich the lives of their relatives and neighbors, and thus build up and strengthen the standards we have reached today.

May we again express appreciation for the forward step taken and express the sincere hope that the lives of these students, pioneering as it were, in a new field, may find all of us, and our children, their companions in classes and recreation, ever ready to aid and assist in every way to make their days here pleasant, profitable and long remembered for kindness, thoughtfulness and consideration extended to them.
Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Blood Indian Higher Education.

We are pleased to report that this office, in cooperation with the Cardston High School Board, enrolled four promising Blood Indian Students in the local High School as of the 1st of the month.

Two boys and two girls were enrolled as follows:

Richard Fox, Age 15 (Anglican)
Taking Agriculture, Science and English, Grade 9 and Math, Grade 8, with complete Shop work.

Wilfred Brave Rock, Age 16 (Anglican)
Taking complete academic course, Grade 9.

Hazel Small Face, Age 15 (Anglican)
Taking complete Academic Course, Grade 9.

Francis Eagle Child, Age 16 (R.C.)
Taking complete Academic Course, Grade 9.

We were at the School yesterday and talked to the pupils and the teachers - after two weeks' perfect attendance the Principal tells me that the Indian pupils are doing very well and that the adjustment between the Indian and white pupil is progressing exceptionally well. The pupils, without exception, told me they found the work hard, but that they liked it and were very happy. Francis Eagle Child, in fact, has given a lecture on Indians before her Grade 9 class and the teacher tells me she won the respect of all pupils and that he was very proud of her. Needless to say, we are proud of the whole bunch and hope that this is only the beginning.

Now as to costs. The Board has agreed to accept limited Indian pupils at a tuition cost of $85.00 per year not to exceed $100.00 per family. This means that tuition costs for the half year for our first pupils will be $42.50 each, or $170.00 - which is payable in advance. We are asking that the Department assume this cost for this year, and it is hoped that you can do so. A voucher, payable to the St. Mary's River School Division, No. 2, for this amount, is enclosed.

My big problem in starting these pupils was transportation. Hazel Small Face lives on the edge of the Reserve, next to town and she was no problem. The
other three pupils however, live some miles away. Mr. Art Coady, senior teacher at the Blood Indian Residential School has children going into the Cardston School from eight miles out on the Reserve. We interviewed him and he agreed to transport Indian pupils to school and back, along with his own for $5 each per trip, providing we protected him with public liability insurance on his car. This I considered fair and have insured his car as a school bus for one year, Mr. Coady paying the fire and theft premium of $2.10 and the Indian parents, or Department to pay the balance of $58.90.

Richard Fox and Francis Eagle Child are being transported by Mr. Coady each day at a cost of $5 each, or approximately $14.00 per month, or $70.00 for five months. If the parents assume this cost, we are requesting the Department to assume the $58.90 school bus insurance and enclose a voucher, with a copy of the policy, herewith.

The other pupil, Wilfred Brave Rock is traveling by train to and from school at a cost of $5 per trip; his father is bearing this cost.

Next year, if all goes well, we hope to have enough students ready for higher education in the Cardston High School to require a School Bus, which we propose to ask the Department to furnish and maintain.

(R.D. Ragan)
Superintendent

ST. PAUL'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Reference your 103-6-5 of November 28 -

I am in agreement with your opinions concerning the St. Paul's Residential School and note that the pupils have not been a success at the Cardston High School.

As you are aware, the Department is experimenting this year with the payment of teachers in three of our Indian Residential Schools. It is felt that by offering them a proper salary schedule and superannuation benefits, we can improve the calibre of teaching in these schools.

At the present time the quality of residential school teachers is low and with the present shortage will probably continue to be so.

It is not only a question of salaries but of superannuation. The Roman Catholic Church has its own "Pension Scheme" but the other churches are unable to provide security for their working personnel in the schools, other than the ministers. It is only human nature that teachers will go to day schools or to provincial schools where pension benefits are available.

Therefore we cannot be too critical of the Indian School Administration of the M.S.C.C., nor of the other church bodies. They have advertised widely and have done their best to recruit
both teachers and workers for these schools. I am sending this letter to you in duplicate so that the matter can be explained to your Indian Superintendents and I feel that by giving them an appreciation of the difficulties encountered by the churches, you will secure their cooperation in these difficult times and with residential school problems.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

At the Council Meeting of October 31st, the Head Chief, on behalf of the Council asked that likely boys be sent to some school to attend classes in the operation and maintenance of tractors as it was the desire of the Council that members of the Band operate our tractors, as far as possible.

I concurred entirely with the Council. During the last year, particularly, we tried to give practical instruction to the boys in the operation of ordinary gas tractors and a diesel tractor in use on the reserve. We found it was necessary to have a qualified white man with them most of the time, and this didn't look like the very best business. I, therefore, interviewed Dr. Carpenter, Principal of the Provincial Technical Institution, Calgary, and ascertained from him that they run 10 weeks courses on the use and theory of gasoline and diesel tractors. I also learned that there was at least one Indian attending the fall course.

The second course runs from January 15th to March 21st, 1940, and we would like to send two young men to attend this course. One of these boys, Gordon Yellow Fly, worked with the diesel tractor this past season, the other is Pat Bear Hat. I think they would both benefit by the course, as they have a mechanical turn of mind.

The fee for the course is $35.00 each, and I figure that $90.00 each should cover all expenses, making a total cost not exceeding $270.00. Would authority be granted to send these boys to the school, and an accountable cheque of $250.00, from the funds of the Band, be issued to meet cost and expenses, please?

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

MR. PATRICK

With reference to the minutes of the Blackfoot Council held on the 19th instant I would point out that it was decided that all costs of Indian education would be paid from Parliamentary appropriation from April 1, 1928.

Owing to lack of funds it will not be possible this year for us to consider payment of tuition grants from appropriation for pupils who desire to enter high school for the first time.

On the other hand, in view of the ruling regarding the payment of education costs from appropriation I feel it would be a mistake to approve payment of any tuition grant from band funds. We have had similar experience in connection with the Six Nations Agency and since April 1, 1928, have refused approval of payment of tuition fees from band funds.

If the practice of paying from band funds is again recognized it will mean that the Department will have no control over the expenditure as quite likely every Indian belonging to the band in question will desire to have his child receive a high school education -- at least that is our experience in connection with Six Nations.

Taking everything into consideration I feel that you would be well advised to notify Indian Agent Gooderham that the Department is not prepared to consider approving the payment of tuition grants from band funds.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Dr. McGill:

I have recently received from the Principal of our Old Sun School (Rev. J.W. House, B.A.) on the Blackfoot Reserve, the following extract from the Minutes of the Blackfoot Council meeting, June 19, 1940, as given to him by the Blackfoot Agency Office:

"Schooling:
The Agent advanced the idea to the Council of having promising Indian school pupils continue their learning in white schools in Gleichen and Cluny, while boarding at the Indian schools. There was considerable discussion after which it was moved by Yellow Fly that the Council authorize the Agent to make arrangements for any boys or girls who were ready for higher education to attend white high schools and if funds were not available from grants, the Band assume the responsibility for expenses, not to exceed $200.00 each per year. The motion was passed unanimously."

Secretary's reply of July 3rd, 1940:

I wish to refer you to the minutes of Blackfoot Council meeting held on June 19th, and particularly to resolutions No. 2 and No. 3 under the heading of "New Business" dealing with the payment from Band funds of fees for advanced education for certain Indians of the Band.
In this connection I have to advise you that since April last, 1928, it has been the policy of the Department to pay expenses of this nature from Parliamentary Appropriation; and that it is not desirable that this expenditure should be made from Band Funds. The resolutions referred to are, therefore, not approved.

I might also add that, owing to lack of funds in Parliamentary Appropriation, it will not be possible to provide grants for pupils desiring to enter high school this year."

As the decision set forth in the Secretary's reply must surely militate against the desire and policy of the Church Societies engaged in Indian educational work, as well as of your Department of Government, to encourage the Indians to help themselves, I trust that this important matter may receive further consideration.

So far as the Blackfoot Indians are concerned, they have ample funds to help any of their boys and girls who wish to do so, to take any higher education which may fit them for greater usefulness amongst their own people or elsewhere. That they themselves are willing to vote funds for this purpose, and have already done so, seems to me to be quite clear from the following information which I have just received from the Principal of our Old Sun School:

"The Indians have already spent band funds to finance Annie Royall in the Lacombe Home (R.C.) and later to take a dressmaking course in the technical School in Calgary. I think this was in 1938 and 1939.

They have also financed Gordon Yellowfly and Pat Bearhat through a Diesel course in the Calgary technical School. This was last winter.

The present resolution applies to any child of either school who is recommended by the Principal and accepted for further training by the Blackfoot Council."

As there are three pupils at our old Sun School who have been recommended for further training, the Blackfoot Band Council, according to the above Resolution, agreed to provide out of Band Funds a sum not exceeding $200.00 per year for each. According to the Principal this would be spent as follows:

Board and accommodation at the School $165. (which is the regular per capita grant): $30.00 for High School fees; $5.00 for books.

One of the pupils is Margaret Crowfoot, a descendant of the great Chief of the same name, the other two are boys, namely George Spotted Eagle and Andrew White Pup."
While it is not altogether difficult, in view of prevailing war conditions, to understand why the usual Parliamentary appropriation cannot be made available for the further education of these pupils, I myself find it difficult to understand why it should be considered undesirable that the necessary expenditure be made from Band funds.

Although a goodly number of the pupils from our Society's other Indian Schools have qualified as nurses, teachers, and for other useful positions in Canadian life, none from the Blackfoot Reserve have achieved the same distinction, and our Commission are, therefore, particularly interested in encouraging and helping any who have manifested a desire and shown the ability to transcend the ordinary and commonplace.

As the ruling given in the letter quoted above cannot but tend to discourage the generous motives so clearly evident in the Resolution of the Blackfoot Band Council and must be as great a disappointment to them and their children as it is to our Commission, I earnestly hope that the decision may be reconsidered, and authority given to the Indian Agent to allow the money voted to be used for the specific purpose indicated.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

Re: Payment of Tuition Grants from Blackfoot Band Funds.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of August 26, in which you submit, for my personal consideration, the desirability of having tuition grants paid from the trust funds of the Blackfoot Band to pupils recommended for high school courses by the Indian agent and the principals of the residential schools on the reserve.

I can readily appreciate the difficulty you must experience in fully understanding the refusal of the Department to authorize these grants when requested to do so from time to time.

The records here indicate that a number of Indian bands throughout the Dominion made provision for tuition grants to a limited number of pupils and that these grants were approved by the Department over a long period of years. About 8 years ago, however, certain abuses developed on one or two reserves and the practice was discontinued. In certain cases the least deserving and the least qualified pupils received tuition grants as the result of unfair influence exercised in the council of the band. On the other hand, a number of deserving Indian pupils, who had appealed for grants and who had been refused, were naturally disappointed from year to year and frequently appealed to the Department for redress.

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D.D.,
Secretary,
Indian & Eskimo Res. School Commission, M.S.C.C.,
38-48 The Bible House, Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.

In reviewing -
In reviewing conditions at that time it was felt by the officials that it would be unfair to ask either the principal of a residential school or the Indian agent to step in and refuse to recommend grants authorized unanimously by the band council. The Department was convinced at that time that the average Indian council was not equipped to create the safeguard that should surround the payment of these grants if band funds were to be conserved and abuses avoided.

The resolution referred to in your communication, received by the Department from the Blackfoot Council, was given very serious and very careful consideration by the officials of this Branch. It was felt, however, that it would be unfair to revert to the old practice and that an exception could not be made in the case of the Blackfoot Indians without creating a great deal of dissatisfaction amongst the members of other bands. You will be interested to learn, however, that the decision of the Department has been somewhat modified in response to an appeal received from Indian Agent Gooderham. The Secretary of this Branch, in a letter to the Indian Agent, dated August 17, 1940, stated in part as follows:

"The whole question has been carefully reviewed and it has been decided to allow the Blackfoot Band to vote funds for purposes of higher education, provided that the pupils assisted in this manner attend either technical schools or take one of the courses provided at an agricultural college. The Department is not prepared to approve payment of tuition grants from band funds for straight academic courses".

This concession, I may state, is granted by way of experiment. There is an acute shortage of skilled labourers in a number of districts in the Dominion. It does not seem fair that Indian pupils should -
should be encouraged to proceed with straight academic courses at this time. In addition to this, we have learned from experience that the average Indian pupil possesses the skills necessary to proceed successfully with a vocational course of training. It is not likely, therefore, that the abuses to which I have already referred will creep into this arrangement.

It is my hope that the decision of the Department will prove reasonably satisfactory to you and to those on whose behalf you have written.

Yours sincerely,

Director.

Ottawa, January 3, 1944.

Mr. G. H. Gooderham, Indian Agent, Gleichen, Alberta.

I have today discussed with the Superintendent of Reserves and Trusts the advisability of selecting, from year to year, a couple of promising Indian pupils, graduates of the Crowfoot and Old Sun Residential Schools, and have these pupils proceed with courses leading to their matriculation standing and later to diploma or degree courses at a recognized technical school or agricultural college. We are of the opinion that the cost in each case, of approximately $500.00 per annum, should be borne from band funds. Indians throughout the Dominion, including the Blackfoot band, are at present enjoying an unusual measure of prosperity. This being the case, we feel that the payment of approximately $1,000.00 a year would result in no hardship to the members of the Band.

We have, as you probably are aware, an item in our annual appropriations entitled "Assistance to Ex-pupils" and amounting to $23,000.00. This fund is used, however, for the institutional care of delinquent Indian boys and girls, for the payment of tuition fees for Indians in attendance at ordinary public schools and for tuition grants to promising Indian pupils proceeding with high school or vocational courses. I may state that during the last two year period there has been a great deal of delinquency, with the result that a steadily decreasing amount of this appropriation is being now used for higher education. You will realize at once that it would be exceedingly difficult to justify assistance from this appropriation for pupils of the Blackfoot schools.

The idea we have in mind is that you and the principals of the schools, R. C. and C. E., might select two promising boys with a creditable standing in their studies and also a creditable record from the
standpoint of moral stability. These pupils would be interviewed with respect to their outlook on life, their legitimate ambitions and their anxiousness to proceed with advanced courses. The greatest care should be exercised in their selection. They should be encouraged to proceed to either a high school in the district, capable of providing matriculation standing, or to Calgary. Upon completion of their high school course, their high school record would be reviewed and a decision reached there, with respect to whether or not they should proceed with a diploma course or a degree course at an agricultural college or a specialized mechanical course at the Calgary Institute of Technology. In view of the fact that the Department has been recently subjected to a great deal of criticism for our failure to provide advanced courses of study for our Indian pupils, it would be appreciated if you turned this matter over in your mind and discussed it, not only with the principals of the schools, but with the responsible members of the Band. The proposals submitted are wholly tentative. It is just possible that you may desire to modify them and that the modifications you may suggest will be equally acceptable to the Department. The only additional thought I want to express is that we are somewhat opposed, as the result of our experience, to straight academic or classical courses for Indian boys and girls. Boys and girls who have taken these courses in the past have been, with one or two notable exceptions, in no sense successful.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

P.S. - There is a feeling here that parents, as such, should be encouraged to bear part of the cost of these courses. You might comment on this suggestion.

May I refer to your 103-104 of 3rd January, 1944 when it was suggested that promising Indian pupils from the Boarding Schools on this reserve proceed with courses leading to matriculation standing. I have to report that a survey of the situation was made at the end of the school year in June last.

The Old Suns School had two boys graduating from Grade 8; Crowfoot school had none above Grade 7, while a boy who had attended the Gleichen Public School passed his Grade 8 tests.

The three boys - Percy Yellowfly, Cecil Crowfoot and Norman Galf Child - are now attending the Gleichen High School.

It was hoped that they would have attended schools away from the reserve, but dormitory or boarding arrangements could not be made and it was only on opening day (Sept.) that the parents and the boy agreed on the Gleichen High School. The School trustees agreed to accept them provided a tuition fee of $60.00 each was guaranteed. Then board and lodging had to be secured. The Galf child boy lives at home; the cost for the others is $25.00 per month. The parents buy books and clothe them.

At the meeting of the 4th, the council passed a minute which read: "Moved by Mr. Baker and seconded by Good Eagle that the sum of $120.00 be allocated from Band Funds to pay tuition and board of Norman Galf Child, Percy Yellowfly and Cecil Crowfoot while attending high school in Gleichen during the current school year."

If an accountable cheque for $700.00 is forwarded, monthly cheques will be issued for board and lodging, and tuition accounts paid as they are submitted by the Secretary of the School Board.

The Indians are very pleased to use their Band Funds for this higher education and all are enthusiastic about the venture. It is hoped the boys make good.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING MARCH, 1945, ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY

Education:

There were 200 pupils attending the two residential Indian Schools and 3 attending the Gleichen High School.

The Mumps epidemic did not break up the routine very badly at the boarding schools; classroom work went on as usual and was much of the same calibre.

At the Crowfoot School, dormitory space was increased by moving the quarters of the senior matron of boys and girls into the hallway and very comfortable and well ventilated rooms were erected over the stairways at either end of the buildings. At this school, the girls are receiving training in typewriting and music as well as domestic and sewing; the boys are not so fortunate; they receive good training in care of stock but no manual training. The Principal is anxious to supply this when a competent instructor can be found.

Despite the fact that there are over 100 children in this school (30 over the grant) they are very comfortably housed and very well fed. The Principal and Sister Superior deserve all the credit.

The Old Suns School is also running smoothly; the Principal Rev. J.W. House, is a capable administrator. He secured the services of a qualified manual training instructor and the boys are now receiving regular training.

There is a need for trained carpenters and mechanics on this reserve and it is our hope and expectation that a few boys will graduate from year to year, who will make carpentry or allied trades their vocation after some apprenticeship.

The boys attending high School did very well this term. They proved one thing, that they can do well when made to apply themselves to this work.

The Old Suns School has a Cadet Company and good hockey teams. The Crowfoot School also has hockey teams.

G.H. Gooderham, Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Ref. your 103-104 dated 3rd Jan.

Advanced Education.

The Blackfoot Band Estimates for 1945/46 include an item "Advanced Education - $1250.00".

During the school year of '44/'45, three Blackfoot boys attended the Gleichen High School at the expense of the band. They were Norman Galfchild, Cecil Crowfoot and Percy Yellowfly. All passed their Grade 8 Departmental Examinations; Galfchild and Crowfoot got a "C" standing while Yellowfly got a "B" and a diploma.

Yellowfly and Galfchild have already returned and Crowfoot is returning today, to take Grade 10.

Arrangements have been made for board, lodging, fees and books, to be paid from Band Funds; the parents clothe the boys.

An Accountable Cheque of $650.00 should be sufficient for the balance of this fiscal year; anything unexpended at that time will be returned and application made for the amount required to finance the rest of the school year.

Please have this cheque forwarded as soon as possible.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

Most pupils returned to boarding schools early in September, but beginners, as usual, are slow to start. Parents do not yet realize the importance of this. It is anticipated that there will be some pupils at our schools who will complete Grade 8 this year; the teachers are better qualified to teach them.

Family Allowance payments are not effecting the attendance at Blackfoot Schools.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31, 1945.

XX XX XX

Education: Two boys are attending Gleichen High School in grade 10; they are doing alright.

There are 200 pupils at the two residential Boarding Schools. They are healthy and happy. Vocational training has been improved and the calibre of the instructors satisfactory.

Classroom work always appears to be lacking in something; possibly this is due to lack of interest by the pupil but it is so easy for a teacher to get in a rut and lack that spirit which the child needs so much to retain its interest and enthusiasm. Indian children love to sing and they are good singers. We need to practice a little more psychology to get nearer the desired results.

All children who were school age and physically fit at the beginning of the term are attending the schools.

At both institutions, the farms produced ample feed for stock. Good milch herds are retained while the flocks of fowl produced sufficient eggs. Some cattle and pigs are slaughtered for school consumption. The Crowfoot School has a splendid lot of pigs. The Old Suns School had a splendid garden on its irrigated farms.

We have your letter of the 6th instant giving the names of the Indian children of the Blackfoot Agency who are attending high school. It is noted in the latter part of your letter that some children who are attending high school are boarding at the Crowfoot residential school and the school management is being paid board at the rate of $30.00 per month and that the funds for this purpose are being provided from Band funds.

This is the first intimation we have received that such procedure has been adopted. Do these pupils receive better attention than the regular grant earning pupils? Are there other children of school age unable to secure admission to the Crowfoot School due to the fact that the accommodation available is being used in the purpose mentioned in your letter?

Please let me hear fully from you regarding the matter.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

PP/MGD
Reference to your letter of 13th Feb., of the above file and to the second paragraph of your letter, I beg to report that this procedure has gone on at this Agency for some time, for your information the High School pupils have now all left the Crowfoot School and are staying at an Indian Home—Phil Running Rabbit—it is a good home close to Cluny High School. There was a disagreement over discipline at the Crowfoot School and the High School girls.

For your information up to the time the High School girls left the Crowfoot School there had been no refusal of admission to the school. The better treatment the High school girls got consisted mainly of transportation via car from the Crowfoot School to Cluny High School and return each day.

The problem of Higher Education for any High School student is difficult, particularly in find them a place to board and attend the white high schools. Mr Gooderham is aware of this whole situation and has seen your letter referred to above. It would now be an opportunity to discuss the matter with him.

Respectfully submitted,

W.P.B. Pugh,
Supt.

Mr. W.D.R. Pugh,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Gleichen, Alta.

Old Sun Indian Residential School
Grade IX Pupils

The report of the Alberta Superintendent of Schools concerning the classroom work at the Old Sun school has recently been received. It is stated therein that pupils in Grades five to eight inclusive received only half-time classroom instruction, and that this arrangement leaves much to be desired.

It is noted, moreover, that Grade nine classes were being conducted in the school. In the circumstances it appears advisable to arrange that no pupils above Grade eight should receive their classroom instruction in this school but should go to the nearest available Provincial, Intermediate and High School.

Will you, therefore, make the necessary investigations at once and return answers to the following questions:

(1) How many pupils in grades above Grade eight are enrolled at the Old Sun Residential School?

(2) Are they Day pupils or boarders?

(3) Is there accommodation for them in Gleichen High School?

(4) What extra costs will their attendance at Gleichen High School entail?

It is the practice, wherever possible, to encourage the attendance of pupils above Grade eight at well organized...
High Schools rather than to attempt their instruction in Residential schools which must necessarily be staffed and equipped with emphasis placed upon elementary education. Such High School pupils continue, if necessary, to be domiciled in the Residential school which receives for each such child the usual per capita grant. The Indian Superintendent by arrangement with the Department pays any additional amount involved to the parties concerned.

You may inform the Reverend Principal of the Department's wishes in this matter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Dear Sir,

I am writing to you again on behalf of Jean Curhan and Edna Constant, whom I gave grants last year at High School. Unfortunately, they neither of them made their Grade. Jean was ill just before the exam so had to miss them, or Edna came down in Health, Home Economics & History. Both girls are very anxious to continue their work, and I think will do much better this year; going to a

Dear Mrs. Paul:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant, in which you state that Jean Cuthand and Edna Constant were unsuccessful in obtaining promotion to a higher Form at the Bedford Road Collegiate, Saskatoon, Sask.

Under existing regulations, I regret that we will not be able to renew the grant for them for next year. We renew grants only when a student is successful in the year's work and is promoted to a higher form.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I am in receipt of your letter re the status of Jean Cuthand or Edna Constant.

Before your letter came, on the 15th Sept., I had heard from the Principal of Bedford Collegiate School saying that Jean could be permitted to Grade XI, on the strength of her attendance last week. Perhaps I was too quick in writing but the time was going on so I feared she would be late in coming so did not wait for Mr. McReynolds' letter. So now I want back of reconsider your decision of Jean. She is very anxious to go on and will make a very good teacher we think. We have an excellent home for her if she can have the grant but failing that, I fear she will have to
Go home. Please do your best to let her have it again this year.

Yours sincerely,

Dr. Paul

Ottawa, March 25, 1948.

Dear Mrs. Paul:

We have your letter of the 20th instant with further reference to Jean Cuthand. As requested in your letter of July 30th, 1947, we have made the following payments to Rev. Canon Bowles, Christ Church Rectory, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan:

1. Cheque for $20.00 for September - mailed October 20, 1947.
2. Cheque for $20.00 for December - mailed January 10, 1948.
3. Cheque for $60.00 for October and November, 1947 and January, 1948, - mailed February 20, 1948.
4. Cheque for $20.00 for February - mailed March 12, 1948.

You will note that the above totals $120.00 and I presume has been paid to Mrs. Smith.

In view of the contents of your letter we will make another payment to Adam Cuthand for the three weeks that she resided with him. As stated in my letter of March 12th, I am extremely sorry that there was a delay in forwarding these payments.

I am pleased to note from your letter that Miss Cuthand is making satisfactory progress and I hope that she will soon be able to return to school. I note that you will then communicate with me regarding the cost of her room and board for the balance of the current academic year.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Mrs. W.E.T. Paul,
Synod Office,
PP/MGD Prince Albert, Sask.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I am again writing on behalf of Miss Curhans.

I may remember that she was obliged to go into the San last spring as she had had to work too hard at her boarding-place & that, together with G. XII., was too much for her.

Today I have had word that she may leave the San & enter Normal School on 14th Sept., so I am hoping that the Dept. will be able to make her a grant, or one that will cover her board & fees. She will not be able to undertake any work other than her Normal studies as the curse is heavy & she will not be able to stand more than that.

Kindly let me have a reply as soon as possible as I must try & find her a boarding-place near the school.

Yours sincerely,

P. Paul (P.M.W.E.T.P.)

Mrs. W.E.T. Paul,
Synod Office,
Prince Albert, Sask.

Dear Mrs. Paul:

Your letter of the 23rd instant reached me this morning and it is noted that Jean Cuthand is being discharged from the sanatorium and wishes to attend normal school.

As previously stated to you, we are quite anxious to help Miss Cuthand but I think you will agree that it is important that we should have definite assurance that her physical condition is such that she will have a reasonable chance of completing the course.

I, therefore, enclose one of our regular forms which you should have completed. This will give us the information required regarding the cost of the course. On the reverse side of the form you will find a medical report form; this should be completed by the Doctor at the sanatorium. As soon as we receive this form properly completed, we will be in a position to make a final decision.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

PERSONAL: RE: WILLIAM NUTTUNNEE

Dear Mr. MacKinnon:

The above mentioned young man has been awarded a scholarship by McGill University, whereby, I understand, he receives his tuition and board during his term at the University.

This young man is a full blooded Indian, has taken his high school courses in this town. He is at present in my employ so I have had a good opportunity of observing him, and I have for him nothing but the highest commendations. He is not, however, a treaty Indian, his father having withdrawn some years ago.

His problem is that he has absolutely no funds. Local people are going to give him some help, which funds, by the way, are going to be handled in his interest by Canon Hives of the Church of England, to which this young man belongs, and Mr. Hock, president of the local Board of Trade. The amount locally subscribed however, will not be sufficient to see this lad through, and I wondered if through the Department of Indian Affairs there might not be some way of giving him financial assistance which will help him to complete his studies.

It is his intention to study law. It is not often that we find a young man of his type among the Indians, and it seems to me that when we do, something should be done where necessary, to give them reasonable assistance. I feel sure you will give this case all the consideration it deserves, and I will look forward to hearing from you at an early date.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) P. Prince,
Paul Prince.
Ottawa, September 8, 1948.

Paul Prince, Esq., M.L.A.,
Battleford,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Mr. Prince:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 3rd, written by you on behalf of the marginally-noted young man who has secured a scholarship at McGill University.

The records of the Indian Affairs Branch indicate that William Nuttunnee is the son of James Nuttunnee of the Red Pheasant Reserve. James Nuttunnee was enfranchised, together with the members of his family, on November 24, 1944. Enfranchisement in the case of this Indian, as in the case of all other Indians, means that he now enjoys the full rights and privileges of Canadian citizenship. He is no longer a ward of the Federal Government. I deeply regret, therefore, that it would not be possible to pay out of the appropriations voted by Parliament for the education and welfare of Indians the amount necessary to pay any part of this boy's expenses while in attendance at McGill University.

It is just possible that the Provincial Department of Education may have a scholarship fund from which this boy might be helped. It is a praiseworthy case and the interest of the local people in this boy's education is indeed commendable.

Yours sincerely,

Jas. A. MacKinnon.

MEMORANDUM:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: William Nuttunnee

I am returning herewith copy of a letter addressed to the Minister by Mr. Paul Prince, M.L.A., of Battleford, Sask. In the letter Mr. Prince asks if there will be any possibility of assisting this young man.

Since receiving your note, I have explored the situation and find that last year we employed several university students in connection with summer schools for Indians. As this young man will be attending McGill, I would suggest that he drop off at Ottawa on his way through and have a talk with Colonel Neary. If he is interested in this type of work I feel certain that it will be possible to place him, as Colonel Neary advises me that they have a summer school at Pelican Narrows, Sask. It might be possible as well to place him elsewhere in Canada.

Acting Director.
THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY

Battleford, Saskatchewan,
September 23, 1948.

Hon. James A. MacKinnon,
Minister of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Re: William Wutunnee

Dear Mr. MacKinnon:

I wish to thank you for your letter of the 17th instant, in which you state that the above mentioned could possibly be placed as instructor in one of your summer schools. In the event that he can not obtain employment in the East, and thereby save the cost of coming West, that would be an ideal arrangement. His big trouble will be, of course, to have enough funds for incidental expenses to carry him through the academic year. A certain amount was raised locally, which will of course be of considerable assistance. Since you are a westerner it will probably interest you to know that he left for the East on a cattle train last Saturday evening, thereby saving the cost of transportation, which is a considerable item when one has to travel that distance. He would not, therefore, on time receive your letter suggesting that he stop off at Ottawa.

Thanking you for your interest in this young man, and assuring you of the appreciation of all those interested in his welfare, I remain

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) Paul Prince.

Your letter of April 7 reached here when I was absent from town. At present, we do not have a seasonal school open to students of your denomination. However, there is a vacancy for Clerk Grade 2 for temporary employment during the summer in our own Education Division here in Ottawa.

We have several applicants for this position, and yet if you so wish, I would be glad to consider you for it. I am sorry we were unable to contact you in Montreal this winter. One of our inspectors did endeavour to reach you, but you were at the University in classes when he called. The salary which I could offer you here is $125.00 a month, and the position will last until you return to university in the Fall. Superintendent Bell has received a request from Clarence Swimmer, son of Andrew Swimmer, No. 242, Sweetgrass Band for assistance to take a one month's course in Acetylene welding. Mr. Bell is given to understand that Andrew Swimmer mentioned this boy's case to Educational Officer Clark, and Mr. Clark intimated that the Department would be willing to assist.

Clarence is 18 years of age and went to grade 6 at Delmas Residential School. Mr. Bell states that he is quite mechanical minded, and shows excellent judgment in the care and operation of his father's machinery in addition to being a far steadier worker than most Indians.

This would be "on the job training" at Rorke Brothers at Battleford. They would charge $175.15 for the use of materials and equipment. His board in Battleford for a month would be $45.00 making a total expenditure of $215.15.

Mr. Bell recommends that this request be granted and in view of his recommendation I would add mine, as it is not a large outlay and a few cases will have to be tried out and the results surveyed to find out if Indians are ready for assistance in obtaining a skilled trade.

May I be immediately advised of the Department's wishes.

We have your voucher No. 885 requesting payment of $6.00 for janitor services at the John Smith School for the month of September.

The previous rate was $4.00 a month for this service and we have no record of having authorized an increase.

Please advise the reason for submitting a voucher at an increased rate.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

PP/MCD
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Reference is made to your letter dated October 22nd,
your file 42109-6 (B-1) regarding our Voucher No. 085
dated October 3rd, 1948 in the amount of $6.00 in favour
of Mr. James Bear for janitor services at the John Smith
Indian day school.

We are experiencing difficulty in securing Indians
to do the janitor work at this particular school at a rate
of $4.00 monthly and I recommend that the rate be raised to
$6.00.

This particular school has a large attendance and
in order to keep the premises clean and tidy the janitor
work entails scrubbing the floors of the school classroom
and children's dining room at least once a week.

I recommend that the increase be authorized and
accounts passed for payment in view of the additional
janitor work entailed.

I regret the error in not having forwarded a proper
explanation in regards to our voucher above mentioned. In
future we will forward vouchers at the rate of $4.00 monthly
until such time as the increase is authorized.

N. E. McLeod,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

Extract from letter of September 20th received from A.W. Moore, teacher of the John Smith Indian Day School. Original on File 610-1:

"For the carrying on of the school we should have janitor service for the furnace and big stove. One of the school boys will act for the sum of ten dollars per month. He will do the sweeping and dusting as well for an extra five dollars. There is a good deal of work involved and I would suggest for twenty-five dollars per month the cleaning, scrubbing and fires could all be done."

In a letter dated September 23rd commenting on the above request, Supt. McLeod wrote as follows:

"Personally I see no reason why this work cannot be done by the older pupils free of charge to our Branch. Coal burning heating equipment has been installed in both classrooms with this type of equipment tending furnaces does not require any great amount of heavy work, in comparison with tending wood burning heating equipment. I will follow the matter closely and if I find that janitor services are necessary a recommendation will be forwarded at a later date."
October 3rd, 1949.

Mr. N.J. McLeod,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Duck Lake, Sask.

Re: John Smith Indian Day School

I desire to refer to that section of your letter of September 23rd which mentions the request you have received for janitor service at the above mentioned school.

We agree with the statements made in your letter, and no allowance will be made for janitor service at this school unless we receive a further communication from you.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re Cote Bay School Fuel:

Owing to late spring and early fall in 1945 our fuel consumption in the above school has been much heavier than anticipated. At present we have about two or three week's supply of seasoned cord wood and with the very cold winter such as we have we will need additional funds to purchase dry wood to carry us through till spring.

It costs us $6.50 per cord to lay it down on the yard and I expect we will need between 15 and 20 cords, and if the severe cold continues much longer we might need even more.

In making our estimates for 1946-47 we quoted wood cost at $5.00 per cord, which at that time was the actual cost. However, since the beginning of winter the Indians were able to get prices far above that in town and in order to compete with the market we had to raise our price in line with the town, which also means that our next year's wood supply may be on the short side. Would it not be possible for the Department to amend our estimates to allow an increase in view of this fact?

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 18, 1946.

Mr. J. L. Bryant, Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, you may secure the additional wood required during the current winter at the Cote Indian Day School.

I note the information contained in the last paragraph of your letter, regarding increased prices for wood. I realize that this is due to circumstances beyond your control, and you can purchase the quantity that you consider necessary, at the lowest price which you can obtain.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

**CANADA**
In our 1947-48 estimates made out last year we quoted an estimated price of $5.00 per cord for wood delivered for the above schools, a total amount of $750.00. As this must cover sawing, splitting, piling and putting in the basement for the Cote School, this amount will not be sufficient as wood is at least $2.00 per cord higher than last year. However, I think I could manage with a $1.00 per cord increase for this year and I would appreciate an accountable cheque for $900.00 with which to purchase wood from the Indians. We have sufficient snow now for sleighing and I always like to get our wood in before Christmas, as it becomes more difficult to get when the snow gets deep and the weather very cold.

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

Re: Voucher No. 145.
Light & Power Cote Day School.
Month of January 1949.

I have for acknowledgement your letter of February 17, 1949, in connection with the above voucher in the amount of $50.65 for light and power for Cote Day School for the month of January.

I wish to advise that the meter reading was taken on February 4, which would cover practically five weeks from date of last reading, also that during the month of January the furnace motor was not properly adjusted.

As the one class room became overcrowded, the dining room is now being used as an additional class room, this also tends to increase the current consumption especially as January was a very dull month and the lights in both class rooms had to be in use most of the days.

The February light bill for Cote School amounted to $29.93 considerably lower than January's account.

Under the circumstances I would recommend that Voucher No. 145 be paid.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent,
Pelly Agency.
24th March, 1949.

Mr. J.L. Bryant,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Kamsack, Saskatchewan.

We have your letter of the 13th instant regarding Voucher No. 145. We have noted the contents of your letter, but we still feel that the account for electricity for January was extremely high.

The teacher should be instructed to watch the consumption of electricity and keep the account as low as possible.

The January bill is being paid.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Funnichy, September 12, 1949.

J. P. B. Ostrander, Esq.,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
P. O. Building,
Regina, Sask.

When making 1949-50 Estimates for fuel at the new Day School at Nut Lake Reserve, Mr. Simpson asked for $250 to buy wood. This money has been forwarded to our office, however, a new coal burning type furnace was installed at the Nut Lake school, and I find that the $250 wood money will not be sufficient to buy wood for the kitchen stove and sufficient coal for the furnace. I would suggest to buy 15½ cords of stove wood, split and piled, at $6.00 per cord - $92.50. The remainder $157 left in this office will be sufficient to pay for 9 ton coal at $15.50 per ton at Rose Valley, and $2.00 delivery charges to the reserve.

* I therefore, request authority to buy an additional 7 ton coal at the same price as already mentioned.

This same mistake was made when making up the 1950-51 Estimates. We regret this error and request that the estimates be changed in accordance with this letter.

A. R. Mixon,
Acting Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter from Mr. A.R. Nixon, Acting Indian Superintendent, Touchwood Agency, and requisition for fuel for the Nut Lake Indian Day School.

As the amount of $250.00 has been forwarded to Mr. Nixon to pay for wood, and coal would be much more satisfactory for the furnace, I would recommend approval of Mr. Nixon's suggestion in so far as substituting coal for wood is concerned. However, I presume it would be necessary to have Mr. Nixon return that part of the $250.00 which is not to be spent on wood, and have the necessary coal ordered by the Purchasing Agent. If it is possible for Mr. Nixon to use the money now on hand to pay for coal, I would so recommend, but I would appreciate receiving instructions in this connection.

J.P.B. Ostrander
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

We have your voucher No. 676 issued in favour of the United Church of Canada covering the cost of thirty cords of wood supplied the Rossville School.

Previously you forwarded voucher No. 190 dated April 26th covering the cost of fuel wood purchased from the United Church for the Rossville School.

29th December 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Attention: Mr. B. F. Neary

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of December 11, 1947 under file 45-123 (W.T.L.), with regard to this Agency's voucher #676 issued in favour of the United Church of Canada covering cost of thirty cords of wood supplied to the Rossville Indian Day Schools.

You mention voucher #190 dated April 26th covering a similar amount of wood, which was also purchased from the United Church of Canada for the Rossville Indian Day Schools.

Voucher #190 covers wood purchased from the United Church of Canada for the fiscal year 1946-47. The reason that voucher did not go forward at end of fiscal year, was that all wood covered on this voucher had not been delivered to the school at the end of the fiscal year, and as there was some question as to the exact amount of wood the United Church had in the district, I refused to pay for same until it was delivered to the yard.

Voucher #676 covers wood purchased from the United Church of Canada for the fiscal year 1947-48. The delivery of this wood was completed in the month of September this year, and was vouchered for October 31st.

I trust this clears this matter.

E. B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM: E. 6896

Agent Goodman's letter is passed to you for consideration insofar as your appropriation is concerned.

Beginning April 1 this agency will have a Bank Account at Winnipeg and it should not be necessary to advance more than current needs at any time.

We no doubt will be in a position after April 1st to process requisitions for the amount you consider will be necessary for the agent to have available in April or May.

Would you kindly advise the agent how you propose to deal with his request for funds.

Chief Treasury Officer.
Under the heading of Administration - Repair and Paint Agency Building & Residence is the item $600.00. This allowance is for the painting of the interior of the Agency Office, exterior of Superintendent's Residence and the Exterior of the Clerk's Residence - all of which are in need of painting.

Under the heading of Medical - Radiograms, Postage etc is the amount of $675.00. In previous years this item was included with the Administration advance, but now that Medical comes under the Indian Health Services of the Department of National Health & Welfare it is listed separately.

Under the heading of freighting - canoe and tractor freight is the amount of $1,000.00. This item is to cover the bringing in of supplies from Wabowden by tractor during the winter months and the shipping of supplies to Inland Reserves by canoe in the summer. There will be very little canoe freight necessary this coming year as most of the supplies have already gone forward by tractor - Johnson Transportation Company.

As the Norway House Agency is transferring to the banking system and we are to return monies on hand as of the 31st of March 1948, it will be necessary that these funds be made available with the Bank of Montreal on the 1st or 2nd of April. To date this office has received no cheque books etc for the installation of the banking system but I assume these will be forwarded by the 15th of March as requested earlier.

(sgd) E.B. Goodman

Memorandum:

DR. MOORE

Re: Henriette Ross, Home of the Good Shepherd,
Forest Avenue and Scotia Street, West
Kildonan, Manitoba.

The above girl was admitted to the Cross Lake Indian Residential School in August, 1933. At that time she was stated to be 5 years of age. Her father was living, being No. 344 of the Cross Lake Band, but her mother was dead. In March, 1942, we received the following letter from the Principal of the Cross Lake School:

"We have two girls in the school: Therese keeper and Henriette Ross who continually upset the discipline. They are both fourteen years old though you would think that they are sixteen. We don't know what to do with them and they won't listen to anyone. We tried everything to make them understand better but it seems useless. We certainly cannot keep them any longer in the school as they corrupt the morals of the young girls and are spreading bad spirit in the school. I cannot send them to the reserve as they are orphans and nobody wants to keep them. We found a place in Winnipeg where they keep girls of that temper. They would accept these two girls under the same conditions that the Department pays for the children here and they would be ready to take them before the end of this month. Could you give us permission to send them right away and would the Department be prepared to pay for them while they would be at the Good Shepherd until they reach the age of sixteen or eighteen."

On February 16th I examined this girl at Inspector Hamilton's request. My impression is that she is a high grade moron, neither better nor worse than probably about 7,500 people who are considered normal citizens of the City of Winnipeg. She has been for two years in a home for criminal and immoral girls and if she is any worse it can reasonably be attributed to that confinement.

It is my considered opinion that in permitting a girl to be placed in such an environment without appointing some person or persons to take a personal interest in her welfare, the department has placed itself in an unfortunate if not actually illegal position. I would strongly recommend that a review be made of all wards of this Department at present in institutions to determine whether or not they are being looked after by interested persons.

With regard to the disposal of this particular case, I would recommend that if any person could be found on her own or any other reserve willing to act as guardian for a short time, that this girl be returned to a home environment.
