these two girls. Doctor Simes was in the city so he accompanied us. After careful questioning of both these girls by Doctor Simes and myself, we were of the opinion that neither of these girls were very much different from normal Indian girls of their age and coming from similar environment. It is my own opinion that the diagnosis of high grade moron would be used by any psychiatrists not familiar with Indians were they to examine 50% of the Indian girls on any reserve.

These girls are both determined to get out of the place where they are now being detained. This institution is a place where immoral women are sent by the courts often for treatment of venereal disease and I very much doubt the wisdom of sending these Indian girls into these associations. I would also question our local position in allowing these girls to be kept locked up in such an institution. I found one of the girls under lock and key in a tiny room and heard reports of handcuffs having been placed on one of them. In attempting to get out of the institution I think the girls show a perfectly normal reaction.

Henrietta Ross stated that she had no relatives at Cross Lake Reserve who would be willing to keep her and she thought that if she could get a job she could make her own way. She told me that she had heard that there were some Indian girls employed at St. Boniface Hospital. As a result of this information I interviewed Doctor Sinclair, medical Director of St. Boniface Sanatorium and he arranged for Inspector Hamilton and I to see the Sister Superior. I explained the situation to the Sister Superior and she took the girl on her staff that day, at the regular salary she was paying her other aides. I understand she is to work in their sewing room.

As regards Teresa Keeper this girl is extremely anxious to return home. She says that she has relatives, I forget whether it was an uncle or a sister, at Cross Lake Reserve, where she could make her home. Re: Henrietta Ross

Replying to your letter 103-125 dated August 4th, 1944 regarding the above named girl.

This girl with another of the maids, Elizabeth Wapack, beat it off for Regina Fair, on or about July 20th. Apparently they solicited a ride to the city from Fort Qu'Appelle with Oil Truck Drivers. These big hearted gentlemen, very kindly gave them One Dollar to secure breakfast on arriving in Regina about 5 a.m. These girls had left without any money and only the clothes, which they were wearing. They visited the Indian Encampment after they had dined. Elizabeth Wapack was taken care of by Tom Chicoose of Pasqua Reserve. She was brought back to Pasqua Reserve on Sunday, July 23rd. On Monday she was brought to the hospital. We arranged for her return to Pelly Agency the following day by train.

Regina office was asked to have Henrietta picked up and returned to the hospital. When she was located she was washing dishes in one of the Cafes. One of the staff of the General Superintendent of Indian Agencies office, was of the opinion that she could not be returned to Fort Qu'Appelle, as she had done nothing contrary to law. This was satisfactory to me. I assured them they were assuming the responsibility for her welfare and behavior. For no reason they phoned the hospital to say that she would be on the bus the following evening and to arrange to have her met on her arrival in Fort Qu'Appelle.

When Henrietta first arrived from Winnipeg we had difficulty in getting her free from Scabies and Impetigo. She was almost as bad when she returned from Regina, as when she first arrived here. While she has been helping some of the time in the hospital, if allowed out at night, any regulations about returning at 10 o'clock were absolutely ignored. She would drift in anywhere from 1 to 5 a.m. The following day she is absolutely useless. At present she is confined to bed following an acute attack of tonsillitis.

There is absolutely no grounds, no matter how long she may reside in the Province, on which to commit her to any institution. If you were going to commit similar cases as hers to institutions, you would have to make provision for 90% of the Indian Girls on Reserves.

The suggestion of paying somebody to keep this girl is not a practical one. This girl will not stay on any reserve away from the bright lights and crowds.

When she recovers we will give her another chance. The unfortunate part is if she ignores the regulations and remains out as late as she pleases it upsets the rest of the staff. The only solution to the problem that I can hope for is that some young Indian boy will come along and take her legally for Better or Worse.

M.D.
Medical Superintendent
Qu'Appelle Indian Health Unit.

The Indians complained about the education the children obtain from the boarding schools. Dear Mr. Neary:

The Hustons have happily assumed responsibility for the care of Betty Carol Monias (Indian) since the death of her father five years ago. The father Swart Monias was from Island Lake and belonged to the Norway House Agency. Betty will be seven years old this coming January. During the past year at Miami she took grades one and two and passed into grade three with a mark of eighty seven percent. Under ordinary circumstances it was our intention that Betty should continue her schooling at Miami.

However circumstances are not to be what one might term normal for us this year. Phyllis our own daughter has completed grade eleven at Riverbend School for Girls in Winnipeg. She goes back for grade twelve at the end of this month. Next June she will enter the hospital to train as a nurse. The reason for this year being other than normal for us arises because of the high cost of our daughter's schooling for this her final year.

In order to help meet this cost Mrs. Huston has taken employment at the school as House Manager. This involves the temporary disruption of our home life. It also means that I shall live alone as a bachelor in the Manse for the next ten months.

This disruption raises the question of what to do for Betty. She is not our adopted child but our own child could not be nearer our heart. She is clever, sensitive and loving and for her sake we must not have it appear that she is but a secondary consideration. It would I believe affect her whole personality.

Our thought is that she should go to Riverbend since it is to be for but a single year. There she would be close to Mrs. Huston and our own daughter. The cost would be in the neighbourhood of six hundred dollars. I can do on behalf of Betty what I could not do for my own daughter. I can go to my friends for financial aid. I do not anticipate any great difficulty.

In the meantime my purpose in writing to you is to request on behalf of Betty's welfare a grant equivalent to that paid by your department on behalf of an Indian child in the average Residential school. Her real father is dead and her mother has remarried. I would also request that the amount go forward from the department payable to "The Riverbend School for Girls" on behalf of Betty. I believe the board of Managers will give a certain discount in view of the circumstances which will help my problem in raising the sum required.

Betty if she is permitted to live will be a remarkable child. She has been taking music lessons and can pick up a tune in a few minutes. Since she was five she has on occasions sung before audiences of three hundred or more. She has qualities for leadership. Mr. Bucat has seen her several times. I think perhaps Mr. Hoey is quite familiar with the circumstances surrounding her life. I do feel that if the Indian Department will give evidence of a desire to help that it will greatly encourage other sources from whom I hope to get help. This may be an out-of-the-ordinary request but I trust the circumstances may reasonably warrant you granting it. I remain,

Yours sincerely,

A.C. Huston

Dear Mr. Hamilton;

Re-Betty Carol Monias,

Betty Carol Monias as you know has been our responsibility for the past five years. During that time you as well as other officials in the department of Indian Affairs have seen her. You will confirm what I may say regarding her mental ability and our personal interest in her welfare. Betty, to make a long story short has been accepted in our hearts equally with our own daughter Phyllis.

Phyllis has been in attendance at the Riverbend School for Girls for the past three years. She is now in her last year; her fees, board and tuition costs us seven hundred dollars. This explains my reason for having to accept work on the staff as business manager. My husband under these circumstances is having to carry on his duties as minister at Miami without my support in the home. You will understand our daughter was unable to get tuition in grade XII studies at Miami.

This having to break-up the order of our home in order to help our daughter through her final year raised the question of what to do for Betty. She will soon be seven years old and is so exceptionally clever and sensitive. She is so much ours in every sense of the word that we felt we could not cast her off as a solution to our problem. We felt she had to get the fullest consideration so I have brought her along with me to the Riverbend School.

Her fees tuition and board are in the neighbourhood of six hundred dollars. The girl's alumnae of the school donated $75.00. We are seeking to raise what we can through personal friends. We did feel that the Indian Department might be willing to contribute the equivalent of that paid by them on behalf of any Indian child in the average Indian Residential School. This request is just for this year and it is made under pressure of circumstances described above.

It certainly seems to me that my request is most reasonable. It is also made on behalf of a child that shows exceptional ability. A child who can pass with high standing through two grades in a single year. She is also being given training in music and dancing. I would appreciate you presenting our request on behalf of Betty to the Department. I remain,

Yours sincerely,

REPORT ON THE INDIAN ELEMENT
AT OXFORD HOUSE
BY
A. SINCLAIR, GAME GUARDIAN

EDUCATION

Of all the needs that present themselves before the would-be student of the overall aspects of a Registered Trapping area, there is always one that resolves itself as the key-point of departure, and upon which all others are dependent.

Such a one in the Oxford House area is Education.

Whilst education may be but a minor need in other areas, it is an acute need in the Oxford House area.

There is a reason for this, and it is the following:

The Oxford House area is composed of one hundred and fifty-one active trappers. All of these but two are Treaty Indians. When the Game Branch officials decided to place an officer in this area in 1945, these trappers did not know the basic rudiments of conservation. Being an isolated group, cut off from most contacts, even those of commercial activity, they had no way of learning at first hand, the benefits nor the results of conservation, therefore their outlook mentally was more or less the same as it was a hundred or so years ago. Viz: "Kill, kill and kill" game. A report was brought in to me by one of my converts to the effect that, his Chief told him the following: "Why should you worry about the enactments of the Government when you have the enactments of God, who put the animals upon earth for your use and benefit. Your choice lies between one or the other".

In this case I had to take urgent measures to correct this distorted viewpoint by calling a general meeting of all the head men and trappers, in which, happily, the Chief was present. I proceeded as follows in part: "It has come to my knowledge that some of your outstanding men, to whom the government looks up to for leadership, have on occasion, let slip some ideas that would tend to confuse and bewilder the minds of those of you who are willing to cooperate in the conservation scheme instituted by the Government. To be explicit, I will quote one of these; (quote) why should you worry about the enactments of the Government, when you have the enactments of God, who Himself put the animals upon this earth for your use and benefit. Your choice lies between the one or the other (Unquote). These are ponderous words indeed, but not necessarily right, and it is my duty to declare them wrong, in that they do not include the fundamental principle involved, which principle is based on the natural law of propagation and survival, also divinely instituted.

It is true that God did put the animals and natural...
resources upon earth for the use and benefit of mankind, but He also put natural laws to govern these benefits. "If wisely used, they will propagate; if misused, they can be reduced even unto extermination.

All those of you who are familiar with the Holy Scriptures, will remember how God in His wisdom has provided the means of governing and protecting every benefit He has set upon earth. For instance, The Church. He has provided leaders to govern this holy institution. Without them, or by their abuse, the church would deteriorate or fall to universal abuse, to be no more, even though it was a divine institution dedicated for the use and the benefit of mankind.

In the same way He has placed upon earth, Anointed Herds, Kings and Government to govern the country, its assets, and its people, with power to legislate on matters concerning the benefits He has placed at the disposal of mankind, well knowing that not all mankind would treat these benefits wisely, and that sometime or other, would deplete them even to the extent of extermination.

Asking the herdsmen what views they had in the matter at hand, each one in turn, gravely condemned the attitude quoted and advised ill presented himself upon the words and explanation presented to them this day, and charging upon matters of conserving the resources for their children, and saying that all should abide by the wise enactments of the Government, I thanked them for this and dismissed the meeting for other important work.

I will now give a second example that will bring out the need for an applied policy of education for these peoples. An old patriarch came for an interview and didn't take up the following matter stating, "I think the Government made a wrong move in expecting that no damage could be done one year in case. If we do not kill it, the wolf will before the snow is gone. If the Government had made an enactment rather to prevent the wolf from getting it, well I'd say there was some wisdom to this enactment".

This is the kind of reasoning which the officer in the field often comes across and brings out the important fact that the officer must ever be on the alert to give the right answer, without offending the reasoning he is trying to correct.

I have reserved to the last, the most important reason why an active campaign should be instituted for the re-education of the populations similar to that of Oxford House.

Indian Element

The Indian element carries with it a number of peculiarities in outlook, mentality etc., some of which are traditional and therefore harder to accept or change to new viewpoints and on top of this, one is confronted with the bewildered state of mind of a race once noble but now fallen to a lower level.
He has been shorn of all initiative and responsibility and in search for a medium, he has come to the press where he expects the rest of society to shoulder his responsibilities for him whilst he shirks duty in almost all walks of life. Indian parenthood lording all responsibility of education for its children to the white teachers without an effort on its part to co-operate in the home and behavior respect, very often with disastrous results. The final result being that the young element is now on the highroad to revolt.

Most of these have come to the press where they refuse to assume any responsibility whatever. Two councillors of the Band came to me one day wanting to know if I could give them any suggestions to a problem they had. "We can not understand our young people today. They have lost all respect for anyone, and even for themselves. They sleep away the best hours of the day and when they get up, they are of no use to anybody." I could only suggest an examination into the parent-control angle.

Even the one redeeming factor that has come to the rescue of the juvenile element which is, that of subjecting the family allowance to compulsory attendance in school, is being turned to naught by the bad example set before them by the grown element cited above.

Facts such as these (and there are others) have a direct bearing on any attempt at their betterment. Take for instance, the rehabilitation scheme undertaken in their behalf. At once the fundamental question asserts itself. Should this ten year plan attain success, and they become well-to-do, then what?

To what extent has their responsibility been nurtured in the meantime that would enable them to assume serious responsibility to funds, liabilities, and other functions of an ordered society.

At once the logical conclusion asserts itself that unless an intensive educational program is formulated and followed up in an energetic manner, there can be but little hope of attaining satisfactory results in any undertaking for their betterment.

This also applies and has bearing to all organizations concerned.

The several elements ought to be overruled:

1. Parenthood must assume its measure of responsibility for the proper education of the children. To attain this, there should be an adult educational system that would deal with subjects of sanitation, knowledge of the relative value of time and things, clean recreation, and a well ordered social life etc. And all elements belonging to the supervision of the several branches, such as the Game and Fisheries, Forestry Branch, Church and School etc., should entertain a sense of duty towards this behavior.
2. The young element could be brought to line by the institution of some kind of drilled life such as a boy or girl scout organization could give, and which would gradually instill and bring to life those early responsibilities that are so important and essential to any community. These clubs should not be subject to any church or guild but rather based on the standards of a sound Canadian Society.

3. Another aspect of this need for an intensive programme of education for the Indian element is this: The Indian is a good copyist naturally. He has copied the mode of life of the white race in respect to housing himself, but he totally disregarded the rules of sanitation to the utter detriment of his health. Pole floors in lieu of the habitable brush floors which could formerly be renewed periodically. Closed in and airless shocks in lieu of the open skylight of the hunting trail, has not contributed any to his stamina so needed to his rigorous life.

Dear Mrs. Snary:

Re: Betty Monias

A letter has just been received from Mrs. R.J. Ross, matron of the Indian Residential school at Fortage la Prairie in which she states that she had spoken to you on our behalf concerning our little girl Betty. She also stated that I might write to you direct.

Betty was accepted into our family circle following the death of her father (Ewart Monias). She was eight years old in January and has been our responsibility since she was a baby of eighteen months. Our association with her parents through the work has been intimate and of long duration. It seemed only natural that both parents should desire that we take care of Betty. This left the mother free to earn without an encumbrance her own living. We have not tried to seek legal adoption of Betty because we felt it was better for her to grow to maturity all the time realizing she had worthy parents. We correspond with her mother who has since re-married and we retain for Betty pictures and letters sent by her father to us before his death.

You will realize that through the years from babyhood Betty has become an established fact in our family. Our own daughter Phyllis is now eighteen so Betty in a sense is our only child. Here at Pine Falls our manse is beside the school. Betty attends regularly. She is in grade three. Twice weekly she takes piano lessons from a Winnipeg teacher. Frequently she sings in public.

Betty attended public school in Miami for almost a year. Last year I was on the staff of the Riverbend school for girls in Winnipeg. Betty was registered there as a pupil with our own daughter Phyllis. Betty has been exceedingly popular everywhere she has gone. Her disposition, personality and mental ability makes her outstanding. Last year at Riverbend she won the award for heading her grade throughout the year.
Betty's fees at Riverbend amounted to more than $600. The department paid $180 toward this amount. We still owe $160.44. I took a position as business manager on the staff so we could finance Phyllis through grade twelve. The fees for both girls was more than my salary. You might check with Miss J.M. Carter the principal regarding the above figures, also as to what she thought of Betty and her prospects for the future.

My present purpose in writing is to request that the department accept responsibility toward paying off the balance still owing on Betty's fees at the Riverbend School. I am not taking the position of one who would dare to point out a duty. The Indian department is under no obligation to send a ward to a residential school for white girls. I merely request that in view of what we have tried to do for Betty that all the facts be taken into consideration. Betty you will agree when the records are checked has cost the department practically nothing while all the time she has been privileged to enjoy opportunities unsurpassed even by white children. We hope that we may be able to demonstrate what such opportunities can do for a child of Betty's ability when she is allowed to mature entirely detached from the Indian environment.

Betty at the present time requires to have her eyes tested and I believe from my own experience as nurse she will require glasses. Her hearing has never been good. Specialists have said she would grow out of that defect. We have seen to it that she has had the regular annual T.B. test and her teeth have been cared for by the local dentist. Right at the present time she should be taken to an eye and ear specialist and in view of her need I would like to request the department to make an appointment and to assume responsibility for the cost. I could take Betty into Winnipeg at the time appointed. Immediately following the noon day luncheon would be most suitable for us who have to reckon with a bus schedule.

Yours sincerely,

(Mrs. A.C.) Marjorie Huston.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No; 34-123 of the 13th October 1934, regarding the Rev: Henry Boissaint's recommendation that Alexis Masson of Cross Lake be granted ex-pupil assistance, being an ex-pupil of the Cross Lake R.C. Residential School.

In reply, I beg to say that I was at the Cross Lake Reserve during last week, and find that Alexis Masson is a man of about 30 years of age; married and has three children, and, with the fair catch of fur obtained this winter, this man should be quite able to complete his house without Departmental assistance. I did not see Alexis Masson himself, at the reserve, as he was away, but this information was given me by Indians, the Manager of the Hudson's Bay post, and the United Church Missionary.

Moreover, it is apparently about 12 years since this man left the school, and if this man is to be considered as an ex-pupil, and be given ex-pupil assistance, after being out of school for so long, there are scores of others who will undoubtedly want the same consideration shown them also. My understanding of an 'ex-pupil', based on instructions sent out some years ago by the Indian Commissioner's office & Regina, is a boy or girl who has not been out of a school for more than two years.

I do not recommend that the assistance asked for in the above case be granted.

Your obedient Servant,

In neither of the above two cases is the individual concerned settling down on the reserve and starting housekeeping on their own account, as per the second paragraph of your letter; neither do either of them really qualify as 'ex-pupils' in my understanding of the term, and I do not consider that the assistance asked for is necessary.

Dear Chief:

I am sending you herewith a number of copies of the Resolutions you brought in some time ago, as you requested, and I am forwarding copies also to the proper officials of the Indian Department.

With reference to the balance of the clauses, relating to the proposal to Colonize the graduates of the different schools on the reserve, and provide them with Horses, Implements, Bulls and Cows, and Pigs and Poultry, I may say that in my own opinion, this would not be in the best interest of such graduates. What would be good for them, would be to discharge from the school healthy boys when they reached the age of 14 years, and let their fathers take them out on the trap lines and teach them to hunt and trap and fish. For generations past the Indians of this northern district have known no other way of earning their living, and it is therefore the natural thing for them to do. To go into stock raising in this country except for local consumption, would certainly not be wise, owing to the high cost of transportation to market, and for various other reasons. You will possibly argue that the invasion of the Indians' natural trapping grounds by white people from outside has so depleted the fur bearers that there are not many left. However, for your information, I may say that negotiations are now in progress on foot between the Department and the Government of Manitoba, to greatly improve matters in this connection, and with good hopes of success, so that in the near future, the fur bearing animals, will be more available to Indians than to the white population.

Whereas the schooling of our children in most cases has not been sufficient to enable them to successfully compete with the white element of the population, and whereas this fact makes it imperative that they be thrown back upon their band, and whereas this latter fact again inevitably brings them often to a lower level than the old standard through inactivity.

16. Be it Resolved therefore, to bring before the Department the following suggestions:

24. Whereas the present deplorable state of our Indians is a direct reflection on certain parts of the administration.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I feel confident that as your present condition enables you to help and encourage our ex-pupils, you may be interested in what has consisted, what may be called our Follow-up System for girls who graduated both in the Residential School before and even after the fire of 1930 and also from the Day School.

Being in Cross Lake, as a teacher both in the Residential and Day Schools, since 1920, I have seen our girls getting married and settled. So in 1933, we have started a Society composed of ex-pupils, either single or married, who came more or less regularly to sew at school to their convenience. We started with seven members and are now up to thirty. At times we have from three to nineteen members at a meeting.

This year we have, with the agreement of R.F. Chamberland, principal of the Residential School, started another branch of sewing for which we are in need and thus apply for a sewing machine and also a certain quantity of material such as cotton, flannelette, print or gingham. Till now, the members have been working, either at home or at meetings, mostly from charity clothes they ripped and made into children and baby clothes; but the material is not sufficient. The women could even prepare for the mothers to be a very simple baby layette.

The Sister Superior, a graduated Home Nurse of the St. John Ambulance Association, who visits our ex-pupils when sick, do all what is in her power for the sanitary living condition, though she is not the Field Matron.

We even have from Remailing Departments, a circulating
Library for ex-pupils.

Now as to Indian Handicraft, the material being so expensive in the locality, we would only try to encourage the few ones who would excel on that line, for it will be very seldom one could make a revenue from it.

We have spoken the project over with Mr. P.G. Lazenby from our Norway House Agency on his visit this week. He seemed interested and even encouraged us. I then made it my duty to interest you to our Girls Follow-up System and trust our requisition will receive a particular and favorable attention.

July the 6th, 1938

Dear Sir:

The different works undertaken by the Indian Department for the Indians' Welfare convince me of the staff's ability and care. Particularly I have been taking great interest in your directions regarding the Indians' questions, and I should admit you seem to meet the different problems with a true understanding.

I feel then encouraged and confident in addressing you the present, dealing with the question of the "ex-pupil's after school training".

It is now generally admitted that the Residential Schools' Graduates' conditions have to be improved. Their standing does not contrast, as it should, with the one of those who haven't received any education.

The Indians' present living conditions are at worst as everyone knows. If the ex-pupils problem has always been difficult to meet with, during prosperity, it is at the present very much harder and more than ever requires a prompt and practical solution.

At the prospect of what they have to do with the scarcity of their means, they are overwhelmed, and keep still, thinking simply their position is hopeless.

This situation has been put to study by the officials of this school, and they have thought to stimulate the ex-pupils by organizing them in a society.

Right Rev. Bishop Lejeunesse has given his approbation, and strongly encouraged the scheme.

The Principal, is the General Director of this society, while Bros. Ménard is the acting Director. Bros. Ménard is pretty well qualified to head this work to success; he has a long experience amongst the Indians, has a clear understanding of their needs and of their weaknesses and has the qualities of a leader.

The main object of the society is to give them confidence and promote personal ambition and prove to them the possibility of improvements with their own resources. It is by no means to make farmers with them, but to initiate them to work and make them realize the results of work.

It has been well inculcated into their minds that they have to depend first of all on their personal efforts and not to expect help from the Indian Department or from elsewhere.
at least before they have given proofs of their good will and perseverance.

This Society has been in action for three years and has twenty graduates as members. The number increases every year.

The first undertaking has been a community garden for themselves. It has proven to be a success. All the members have worked steadily and have proven themselves really to be well minded and willing to better themselves. This spring two acres of potatoes and different vegetables have been sown, what will certainly help to solve the food proposition. This work is a success and it will be easy to put it on a larger stand.

This has enabled us to see the results. It has influenced them. Their ambition has been whetted and they certainly have made noticeable improvements in their own gardens and in their general way of living. Of course it is only a beginning and one's could not expect thorough changes. Nevertheless it is a step forward and I am sure that with a prudent direction we should have better results still.

I have to notice this was done by their own means. They have been supplied practically nothing in food or tools and this purposely so they will make their mind from the very start and realize that with their own efforts they can do things if they only try.

However I will ask to point out that they have needed encouragements, and most of all examples. Bros. Ménard has not spared himself. He has joined them in their work and this without expecting any remuneration of any kind, what he will do in the future.

This summer they have undertaken the building of a roothouse for which you have been asked a small quantity of lime and cement. I think the work will be completed this fall if we receive the requested material. This will enable them to keep their vegetables and save their seeds for their own end for the community gardens.

The next thing to promote is proper housing. Very few of the ex-pupils have their own houses and they can not practically meet with these needs in their present conditions. We are at the point now to depend on some help. It is in this mind I have asked you through the Indian Agent some help and building material for a couple houses, which will be erected this summer. It is the only requisition we want to put in this year. It is undoubtedly needed if we want to keep the progress going.

For next year what will be asked for will be building material for four or five houses, the same quantity and quality for each house as we have requested this year. If a smaller quantity of food could be available it would be in many circumstances of great importance. As much as possible we insist that they provide food for themselves when they work. As you are aware of it is not always available and hinder the work. However if the Indian Department is not prepared to assist them in this regard we will try to strive without it, but again it would be of great help.
Re: Girls' Society:

I was very thankful for being promised a sewing machine. Unfortunately I am still waiting for same which I hope will be sent in before closing of the navigation season.

Naturally, if you are interested in obtaining more particulars and full informations concerning both "Boys' and Girls' Societies", I would be just too pleased to fully inform you on their organisation as well as on their management.

Hoping this will meet with your approval and devoted patronage I beg to remain

Yours very sincerely:

Dear Sir:

I have been pleased to receive your letter of September tenth. I sincerely thank you for the sewing machine forwarded to the Girls' Society. I greatly appreciate this donation as it meets their needs and will certainly promote their ambition. Your interest in the ex-pupils' societies is a welcome help.

Re: Boys' Society.

The extraordinary work we had to carry on last fall, has hindered, to a certain extent, the progress of this society. However, the proposed roothouse (16'x20') has been built. As we had none of the requested materials, we had to build up with logs! It can remain so for a couple years, when a good masonry work could be made. In the meanwhile the stones will be brought on the site.

This year's crop has shown important improvements on last year's: 130 bushels of potatoes, 42 sacks of turnips, 15 sacks of carrots, and also onions, lettuce, radishes, peas, beans, corn in rather small quantities, mostly for experimentation purposes. We are very well satisfied with the results and confident to have greater success still as the field will improve.

The total production may not seem very important. Nevertheless, it is progress, and it provides only seeds for the community and the "farm gardens" that it will make noticeable change, as many as the past years could not seed their own plots for lack of seeds. However, everyone of the members get from this source an appreciable help for food. At the present, it does not correspond yet to the needs, but will in the future, gradually, be carried out so the whole production will be proportionated to the consumption. Also, by the fact they will get familiar with these vegetables on the community garden, they will urge more to raise them on their own. This point alone merits consideration. It would help considerably to solve the food question to their health's benefit.

We look forward, as I mentioned to you in my last July letter. The good housing proposition has to be dealt with. We can't expect any progress as long as they migrate from one house to another, crowd two or three families in one place. Besides all the inconveniences for hygiene, education of children, etc., it kills personal ambition. They simply will not improve their homes, their gardens and get interested in something than they have nothing. There is a great deal of time lost to the prejudice of their general welfare.

The handicap, to overcome this situation, is their poverty. They need more than encouragement for this work; they need help. In this view, I am enclosing a list of building material, I will be thankful to be granted with. I also give you the names...
of those who intend to erect a living house next summer. I want to point out, however, that this material is asked for the society and will be handed only to those who will build the walls of their houses and show an intention to finish the work. These buildings will be put up in an united effort of all members. The necessary logs for the walls and for the lumber, will be cut this winter and as our sawmill is operating now, it makes our plans easier.

I trust you will be prepared for such an action. I realize that the amount of money required is important, but the realization of this plan should prove effective for our graduates' welfare.

The tools requested are needed for the erection of these houses and will prove very handy for the different carpentry work they have to do for themselves. I just requisition the essential tools for the present. Last year, I had given this list to the Indian agent and never got any answer.

In a couple years of time, the different works undertaken should have assured the necessary vegetables and the proper houses. We ought then to have them interested in carpentry work and homemade furnitures, the building of scaffolds etc., etc., can be an action of course, needs preparation and for this purpose has to be done next summer. However, we have to do something in this regard. Times have changed. Practically nobody can afford to procure himself a canoe. The same applies for furnitures. It is this intention that brings me to ask for pitch and sugar. We are going to make a couple adits for the very necessities. The possibility and utility of such a work is a sure thing. Time is the main factor required. At the present we are not ready to meet with these necessities.

Let Girls' Society.

The progress of this society is satisfactory. Themselves, they have not so much to be taught about housekeeping, and all other household works. If they only had the necessary things and a more determined will, the situation will be improved at once by a great deal. The attention given to them, the encouragements they receive have caused some changes.

Let us add as conclusion that to head this work to success, patience, perseverance, effective help at the right moment, united action are required. We should never imagine to hang an easy or immediate success. The past experiments should make away every delusion. However, I am convinced that a careful, intelligent and persevering action has to bring out some improvements. This should encourage us to give ourselves up and do what is within our reach.

You will be favoured with Mr. G. Lazenby's visit. He is our Indian agent and you will have nice opportunity to get more particulars.

Reverend Medea:

I have your letter of February 10th, and I am glad to know that you are pleased with the sewing machine which has been provided.

I am interested in what you say about your ex-pupils earning a little now and then by knitting. I believe there is a possibility of opening a market for well-made socks, and I shall be pleased if you will send a sample pair of men's white cotton socks. The wool should not be very heavy, as the call for these socks is from men who work them in connection with various sports, such as skating, and badminton. When I see a sample I will be able to let you know what we can do in this connection. We have had socks knit of heavy wool for $1.50 a pair, and I presume that for socks knit of finer wool, payment would be at any $3.50 a pair.

We have found that the Indian women need a great deal of supervision, as their tendency is to make the socks too short and too wide. They will need to be instructed to make them of a size and shape suitable for white persons. We find it necessary to make the same criticism regarding the beaded mocassins, for which there could be excellent sale if the shapes were suitable.

Several years ago in a number of reserves the department supplied materials for making layettes for babies, and I regret to say that the result was that even those families which could well afford to provide these layettes refused to do so because others were receiving them free.

Reverend Sister St. Luke,
St. Joseph Residential School,
Cross Lake,
via Norway House, Man.
I think it is a wise policy to adopt that Indians should learn to give something in exchange for what they receive. For instance, if an Indian woman can knit, it should be possible to arrange with her to make two or three pairs of socks (with the wool provided for her), and instead of receiving money, give her the necessary flannelette. Or if she can do bead work, take something of that sort in exchange. These, of course, are details of negotiation best worked out locally, but if you have a group of good knitters who will knit according to a good pattern and produce standard quality socks, I think we would not have any difficulty in supplying you with enough wool to start this project. You might be surprised at the way this sort of thing develops, and we are ready to give every possible assistance in marketing, providing the women are willing to work under supervision, and if persons like yourself will arrange to give careful inspection before any payment is made.

Cross Lake, June 21, 1939.

Dear Sir:

We have purchased the different material for the St. Joseph Ex Pupils Association, according to the permission given by your letter 34-123 or 173. I am enclosing the invoices and will be very obliged if you would attend this matter.

You will remark that we have changed a couple articles for bits and auger, which we thought afterwards, will be more needed.

I have to thank you again and heartily for your well appreciated co-operation. The results of our work are very encouraging. The ex-pupils have seeded their community garden and have increased it. This has influenced them to have one of their own, and this year practically every one of them has his home garden.

The example set by the ex-pupils has had good effect on the whole reserve. I think that never yet have the Cross Lake Indians made so many and so large gardens. Of course, it could be still better, but I am sure that the more progress that this association will do, the more also will the Indians on the reserve improve.

The erection of the proposed living houses will soon be started. We are so much busy this summer that we can not give as much time as we would desire. However we try to have the plan going on.

Next fall I hope to be able to give you an interesting report on the activities of this society.

Your very obliged,

Dear Sir:

I am late to report you the activities of St. Joseph Ex. Pupils' Society. No doubt you understand that the reconstruction and opening of the Residential School has surcharged us and hinder all other activities to a great extent.

The Ex. Pupils' Community garden has given satisfactory results, not so good, however, as we could have expected. We had too much moisture and cold during the first part of the summer. I have to say also that without having been neglected, it was not look after with all the care it should have been. Brother Édard who always takes a great part in that work as supervisor and as exciter and who puts even lot of his time, was held up by freighting over whiskey. Jack Forage the whole summer long. Many of the seeds belonging to this club were being steam on the construction. All this together has prevented to give to the garden the proper care. The crop is not so good as it should have been and the members admit it is partly their fault. However, we look forward with confidence hoping that this small failure will convince them that we have to help Providence and nature.

The scheme for the erection of living houses has been successful. Four new buildings were put up and are quite decent for Indians. Two others that had been started previously were completed. It makes a total of six inhabited houses that were not last winter. With one more that could not be finished last fall, you have all what was done in this regard last summer.

Mr. Horace Halcrow, who made an economic investigation last month, has noticed the progress of our ex. pupils and will certainly recommend this work. I am very openly that it is not perfect yet, and that there is still lots to be done. However, I think that it is a good start and that we should be satisfied and encouraged to go on with this scheme.

I am enclosing a list of building material and of tools, with the confidence you would be able to meet with these needs. We had mails left over. The tools have proven very helpful and are in good shape. Brother Édard give his special attention and you may rest assure that they will be well looked after.
St. Joseph's Indian Residential School
Cross Lake, Man. February 24th, 1940.

-2-

You may wonder about the amount of roofing paper I am asking for. A certain number of our ex-pupils' houses need new roofing. It is to meet with this need I am asking for extra paper and I would be thankful if you could do it. The Indians' actual economic stand puts them in the absolute impossibility of securing for themselves anything else than food. If we neglect to keep their houses, it will mean afterwards heavy expenses at one time.

I am including a certain amount of paint, I think necessary and important to protect the windows. I believe it is worth the expenditure.

I feel very obliged to you for the effective co-operation you have given us. I understand that the Department will have to face severe conditions. However I sincerely wish that you will be still in the position to continue us your help.

Dear Dr. McGill:

When I visited Norway House recently I was interviewed by members of the Cross Lake Band who asked whether provision was made for the establishment of a boy who graduates from the Residential School. They told me that it was the policy of the Department to provide a small amount of money so that the young fellow could purchase hardware, windows, and a door for the log house which he would erect. I did not gather that the erection was done by the Department.

Further, I was told that it was the policy of the Department to assist in breaking a small amount of land surrounding the house so that he could grow a garden.

I was delighted to have this information, which I trust is authentic. May I ask if this is the policy of the Department, and just how graduates from the Norway House Residential School and the Brandon Residential School who may belong to the Cross Lake Band are to go about it to secure this very necessary assistance? Is it necessary for the Principal to report the boys who have been discharged for whom this provision is required?

I shall be glad to hear from you on these points as soon as possible.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor Dorey:

With reference to your letter of July 24 provision is made in the current year's appropriation for a small amount to be used as assistance to ex-pupils of Indian residential schools.

The funds at our disposal are so limited that they only permit making individual grants of $100.00 to $150.00. Such grants are only made to ex-pupils who are recommended by the Principal of the residential school concerned and the Indian Agent as being likely to make good use of the equipment provided for them.

In the case of boys we allow grant for the purchase of material to build a house or for farming machinery. As regards the girls we allow either a sewing machine or some articles of household furniture if they are married. Grants are only allowed to those ex-pupils who have settled down within three or four years of the date of their graduation from a residential school.

Dear Sir,

I am writing you direct as our Indian Agent, Mr. Lazenby, is sick and forbidden by the Doctor to touch any business.

Dr. Dorey sent me a copy of your letter to him dated July 30/40 re grants for ex-pupils of Indian Residential Schools. I am particularly interested in the Cross Lake boys this year. I had given the Agent the information I had and he was going to get further details or needs on his trip to Cross Lake. Instead of making that trip he went to bed and the Doctor says he must touch no business for at least a month. I therefore would recommend and ask that the following grants be made this summer.

Re Ross Hardy (boy) graduate from this school in 1936 at 18 years of age. Since going home he has proved steady and hard working. He has been trapping with his father and has done well. With his own proceeds he has bought materials for a house which he wants to establish his own house this coming year. He plans a building 21 x 22 and already has purchased doors, windows, shingles (in part), nails, paint, tar and building paper, burlap for inside finish, curtains, blinds and curtains. He has the rough lumber ready for the work and 60 logs ready for building the walls. He needs the following and I would recommend that these be shipped to him this spring c/o the Indian Agent here:

- 1 Sheet Beaverboard 4 x 6
- 10 Rolls Shingles
- 100 lbs shingle nails (for shingles & beaverboard)
- 575 ft. fir flooring
- 1 Cook stove
- 1 Heater

Re Fred McKay, graduate from this school in 1937 at 18 years of age. The last year in the School he developed a T.B. infection in his leg which eventually led to amputation. The Department supplied him with an artificial limb and he is doing his best to help with the family living. In the winter he looks after the cattle and household at home while his father and brother are away trapping. He is quite handy with a saw and plane and makes a little income through carpenter work. If he had a set of tools of his own he would be in a position to earn a great deal more and is anxious to do so. I would recommend that the following tools be sent him this spring c/o the Indian Agent here.
1 Hand Saw
1 Rip Saw

Dear Sir,

I am writing you direct as our Indian Agent, Mr. Lazenby, is sick and forbidden by the Doctor to touch any business.

Dr. Dorey sent me a copy of your letter to him dated July 30/40 re-grants for ex-pupils of Indian Residential Schools. I am particularly interested in three Cross Lake boys this year. Re Rose Beardy (boy) graduate from this school in 1936 at 18 years of age. Since going home he has proved steady and hard working. He has been trapping with his father and has done well. Dear Sir,

I have just returned from visiting the inland reserves at the treaty time and I am submitting again the list of material for assistance to certain Cross Lake pupils, grant for which has been sanctioned by your letter of June 12th.

I have personally investigated the boys mentioned as meritng assistance and I am satisfied that they are in positions to make good and immediate use of the materials.

I regret that, owing to my absence, and also to the fact that I wished to satisfy myself that the assistance given would not be wasted, the season has now advanced so far that we in the North are already thinking in terms of the close of navigation. I would appreciate, therefore, if these materials could be shipped immediately. They would require to be sent:

Cross Lake,
c/o The Selkirk Navigation Co.,
Whisky Jack Portage,
via Warren's Landing.

I received some time ago an application through our Cross Lake Missionary for assistance in building to Robert Ross, a graduate who left the school a year ago. He was in school 5 years, leaving at graduating age with a grade 6 standing. I examined the dwelling house which this boy with the assistance of his father, is erecting, when I was at Cross Lake a week ago. The log house foundation, planks, beams, and rafters are completed for a house of really excellent type, the type that we have been urging for construction on the reserves. It is 28'x18', with partitions for four rooms. In addition there is a lean-to kitchen. It is unfortunate that this building was inspected so late in the season, as it should be finished before the winter. I am enclosing a list of material which this building requires and if you can do anything about the supplying of at least a part of this material, such as the shingles, doors and windows, before the close of the season, it would be an undoubted incentive to the construction of good buildings. Mr. H.A. Hoey,
Supv. of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I have yours of August 25th advising me of the instructions to ship from Winnipeg materials for the assistance of certain Cross Lake ex-pupils in house building.

I wish to express my appreciation of your prompt attention to this matter. Receipt of this material this year will give much encouragement to the ex-pupils who have spent the summer in the erection of the "block" part of their buildings.

I feel that this assistance will meet a definite need on those of our Indian reserves where the houses are occupied during all, or the greater part, of the year. This does not apply to all our reserves as yet, as some live in their tents and trapping cabins much more than in reserve houses. However, where we have opportunity to assist in the erection of comfortable and houses to replace the small all-contained one-room variety now common in use, I feel that we can do more to advance the living and health conditions by giving such assistance (properly supervised) than by any other means. It is notable among the Indians, but, I think, very natural, that improvement in living conditions inculcates a spirit of independence, a more practical appreciation of the value of industry, and a sincere desire to stand on their own feet.

I trust that this assistance will be continued in those cases where industrious habits would warrant it. To assist indiscriminately, and not solely as a reward for effort, would merely defeat the objective of fostering industry and independence.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
"Principal."

re: Cross Lake School
Attention Mr. Phillip Phelan

Dear Mr. Phelan,

There are on the Cross Lake Indian Reserve about 15 ex-pupils of the Cross Lake School that the Principal would like to help in the building of a home.

For this purpose he recently requested that the Department pay to the Manitoba Province the timber permit for about 25,000 feet of lumber. The logs will be sawed at the school mill. The dimension lumber and boards so provided will be used to build homes for all these ex-pupils.

All the window and door frames, the sash and doors will also be made at the school by the ex-pupils in their own workshop and under the direction of Brother Menard who is acting as manual instructor at the school.

As these ex-pupils have absolutely nothing of their own, it will be appreciated if the Department will supply ten axes, six spades, one cross-cut saw, the glass and hardware for the doors and windows. Nails in sufficient quantity must also be included in this bill of goods.

With this help, we intend to establish in their own homes between 10 and 15 ex-pupils. We hope that, when this building programme has been completed, you will be good enough to send an inspector from the Department in order that prove may be had of the use made of all materials supplied.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

Rev. Father Plourde phoned this morning with reference to a communication he recently received from Brother T.R. Menard of the Cross Lake Residential School.

It appears that there is unoccupied provincial land with an area of approximately 4 x 3 miles near the Cross Lake School which Brother Menard considers would be an ideal location for a muskrat farm. If this land could be secured for the purpose mentioned from the Provincial Government of Manitoba, Brother Menard's idea is that a muskrat farm could be handled under the direction of the management of the Cross Lake School and would provide an opportunity not only for the ex-pupils of the school, but also would enable the school management to train the older male pupils of the Cross Lake School in the proper handling of muskrat.

Father Plourde understood from Brother Menard that the latter was in Winnipeg recently at which time he had an opportunity of interviewing Mr. Stevens of the Lands & Forests Department of Manitoba. He outlined his proposal to Mr. Stevens who appeared to be very favourable to it. Owing to the condition of his health Father Plourde is obliged to leave Ottawa immediately and will be absent for about two months. He was anxious that Brother Menard's proposal would receive Departmental consideration and any further information can be obtained by writing direct to Brother T.R. Menard at the Cross Lake Indian Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

I am just in receipt of your letter of June the 30th and as our next mail will leave here only on the 29th I am sending you an answer by a special occasion.

First I wish to express you in the name of the ex-pupils and in my name our sincere gratitude for securing us a shingle machine. It will contribute a great deal to make the houses of the ex-pupils more comfortable and of better appearance.

As far as I can see by your letter and by the copy of purchase order this machine will not reach us before the end of August so it means that before it could be put in operation it will be already late in September; so it will be impossible for some of the ex-pupils to have their houses completed before freeze up. In fact some of them would have already completed their houses if they had roofing and doors.

As for the windows and doors they could not be made locally this year. Next year we could make the doors here if we were supplied some 3/8 inch veneer for the panels of the doors. As for the windows we don't think we could make them here, but the doors we could make them at the cost of $5.50 each.

In my letter of April 24th I had also asked for some building and barred paper. Révérend et bien cher Père,

Etant de passage pour quelques jours chez Son Excellence Monseigneur Lajeunesse, j'en profite pour vous envoyer quelques notes sur le Cercle St. Joseph des Anciens élèves de Cross Lake.

Depuis la convention de St. Boniface, je ne crois pas que vous ayez reçu de rapport sur le Cercle St. Joseph. Fondé déjà depuis sept ans, le cercle ou société St. Joseph fonctionne toujours malgré toutes les difficultés du commencement.

Pour être bref, je vous fais ici une liste des principales œuvres de la société: Elle a aidé à la construction de 17 maisons nouvelles et à la réparation de plusieurs autres.

Il y a trois ans un chantier de 10,000 pieds de bois était scié pour eux. En 1944, 12,000 pieds et cette année encore un chantier de 400 billots a été fait il y a deux semaines.

Une boutique a été aménagée depuis plusieurs années avec des outils fournis par le Département, l'école et la Société elle-même. Beaucoup d'anciens en ont profité pour réparer canot, traines, traveaux, etc., et pour faire aussi des raquettes, armoires, bancs, tables de toutes grandeurs, etc.

L'année dernière, une belle barge de 34' x 6' a été construite avec les anciens pour le transport pour les compagnies de fourrures et surtout pour leur approvisionnement de bois sec pour l'hiver. Cette barge est évaluée à $200.00. Chacun s'en sert à tour de rôle en payant une piastre ou plus et cet argent est mis de côté pour les réparations futures.

Pour les jardins coopératifs, c'est assez difficile dans le moment. Depuis trois ans les jeunes gens s'en vont travailler un peu partout en dehors, nous avons donc décidé d'en encourager les jardins particuliers et au printemps on va faire un grand mouvement coopératif pour les labourer et les ensemencer de patates et légumes et chaque famille verra à l'entretien de son propre jardin. Ce sera le seul moyen d'y
intéresser aussi les femmes et les enfants, le temps ne leur manque pas.

Maintenant quelques mots sur les besoins de la Société pour l'année courante.

Pour le travail de coopération, nous manquons de tout, je me demande si vous ne pourriez pas nous obtenir de l'Armée par l'entremise du Département des Indiens, plusieurs tentes de différentes grandeurs pour 3 ou 5 ou 8 hommes; des toiles imperméables, batteries complètes de cuisines et mêmes poêles. On formé plusieurs écoles militaires et camps, peut-être pourrait-on avoir aussi d'autres outils, pelles, haches, etc., enfin tout ce qui peut servir, ces gens sont dépourvus de tout pour travailler.

Sur toute la réserve il n'y a que deux charrues pour 150 familles et plus. Il en faudrait une spécialement pour la société.

Nous voudrions faire au moins 20 portes mais pas moyen d'avoir de veneer ou Masonite de 4 ou 3/8 pouces. On nous le refuse pour la guerre, je pense que le Département pourrait nous obtenir près de 300 pds. carrés de l'un ou de l'autre.

Monsieur Doucet avait promis aussi des livres pour métiers: menuiserie, forge, mécanique, peinture, jardins, nous avons encore rien reçu.

Bien cher Père, nous avons bien des jeunes de bonne volonté, nous comptons sur vous afin qu'ils ne se découragent pas. J'espère que ces quelques notes seront suffisantes pour vous faire connaître nos activités et nos besoins et nous avons espérer par votre entremise d'être aussi bien compris auprès du Département des Indiens.

Je vous remercie donc d'avance pour votre aide généreuse, vous assurant aussi le concours de nos faibles prières pour l'amélioration constante de votre santé. Je demeure votre tout dévoué en Notre-Seigneur et Marie immaculée.

(Signée) Frère T.R. Ménard, O.M.I.
Cross Lake, Manitoba.

Reverend Father,

On March 19, 1945, Brother Ménard sent you a report concerning the activities of the Saint Joseph Club of the older pupils of Cross Lake, and, according to news received from Cross Lake, Brother Ménard has received your reply in December last. He has also received in good order the requested supplies, for which he thanks you very much.

Activities of the Saint Joseph Club in 1945.

Last year, as in the past, the Saint Joseph Club of older pupils has improved or enlarged approximately 10 private gardens; it helped to the construction of four houses and several improvements were made in other residences, such as flooring, cupboards, tables; moreover, about ten outside toilets were constructed since the visit of Mr. Moriss in 1944, without taking into account those which had already been constructed thanks to the initiative of the Saint Joseph Club. The Saint Joseph Club has been granted this year a permit to cut 20,000 feet of lumber to provide for the needs of the members to the making of over a thousand fish boxes, and the Club even foresees the sale of several thousand feet of lumber because that business seems to be more promising.

Saint Joseph Co-operative Society.

Now that lumber will be cut on a co-operative basis, because the Saint Joseph Club will be organized as a co-operative to teach the Indians to protect their rights and their gains against the invasion of outside business. From now on, that Club of older pupils will operate under the name of Saint Joseph Co-operative Society.
Until now the Saint Joseph Club has done its best to improve the social condition of the Indians, and thanks to the initiative of the school and to the relative help from the Government it has been successful. But civilization progresses towards the North and threatens to invade the Indians' mode of living; it is certain that if the latter do not organize, the people from outside will take hold of any business which could be a financial help for our older pupils unless they are taught to organize to protect themselves against the invasion by outside business. For example, Brother Ménard wants to teach them, during the Summer, the transportation of goods which arrive from Cross Lake through Wiskey Jack portage, and, during the Winter, the transportation of the fish caught commercially; he also wishes to teach them to act according to co-operative principles in the lumber manufactured by them and in (kinds of) all other business, such as the manufacture of furniture, fish boxes, etc.

The School Share.

In order to help our older pupils, the school is ready to do its share, but it also requests Government help. For example, it is ready to put the saw-mill at the disposal of the Society provided a slight compensation for the depreciation of machinery is granted; or else, it wants to abandon in their favour the Summer transportation on Wiskey Jack portage, that is, it is willing to put at their disposal the truck and storage places.

Government Help (shop)

Thirdly the School wishes to build and furnish a shop which could be used for the manufacture of toboggans, cupboards, tables, boats, and to the repair of canoes, etc. According to our plans, it will have a basement which will be used as a garage and storage by the co-operative. We want a modern shop, which is impossible to get unless Government help is granted, such as cement, building paper, interior furniture, including necessary machinery: motor, universal machine, wood-lathe, ribbon-saw, sander, forge, etc. The older pupils would be prepared at the saw-mill.
Government Help (Tractor)

As the transportation of fish caught during commercial fishing operations is a fairly big problem and as everything indicates that more extensive fishing will take place in the future, certain outside initiatives show the desire to take over that transportation; should this be done, they would take away ipso facto from the Indians a considerable financial income, so say the least, $4,000, which would deprive several families of their only means of livelihood during the Winter due to the fact that fur-bearing animals become scarcer around Cross Lake.

We have thought that the older pupils, under the direction of Saint Joseph Co-operative Society, could organize themselves for the transportation of fish caught during commercial fishing operations if the Government were willing to supply a tractor, with trailer.

Questionnaire.

I have on hand a questionnaire about the various activities of the residential school which are in operation or which are to become in operation at the school and on the Reserve. One of these questions is as follows: Has any attempt been made to organize some form of cooperatives on the Reserve? In order to reply to it, we declare that we intend to organize a kind of co-operative society with the older pupils who are ready to establish that form of society since, during the past 10 years, they have joined the Saint Joseph Club for older pupils, which has been very successful with the little means they have at their disposal. Now that the social conditions of the Indians are improving steadily....the Saint Joseph Club is no longer in a position to operate alone, the requirements of their standard of living, which is becoming modern little by little, even in the North. For example the Indians are unanimous to say that within a few years, hunting and fishing will be insufficient to provide for themselves. This is why we believe that the cooperative is the best social form which could meet their present needs. We will help that way our older pupils to improve their social condition and we will thus meet a wish which the Government has mentioned in the questionnaire which was sent to us.
But, once more, we cannot comply with the Government's wish if it does not agree to make the necessary sacrifices to start that movement. The Government should therefore help us in the construction and installation of the shop which is mentioned above and in the purchase of the tractor. This would enable the older pupils to make the transportation of goods during the winter and of the fish caught during commercial fishing operations. The tractor would also be a big help in the cartage of logs, which becomes more and more important every year.

The Episcopal Corporation has already bought a farm tractor (Farmall A) for the Cross Lake School, and two other tractors for the schools of Sturgeon Landing and Beauval; we believe that the Government, now, should supply the tractor to the co-operative society of the Older pupils of Cross Lake School.

Share of Brother Ménard in the Society.

This Society is under the direction of the school. We are ready to free Brother Ménard from all other occupations and to give him the responsibility of that movement, for which he possesses the necessary qualities. Thanks to the experience he has acquired in the course of the past 10 years while directing the Saint Joseph Club for the older pupils. More than anyone else he has hopes of success in view of the ascendancy he has over the older pupils whom he has known when they were boys at school.

Mitigated Co-operation.

Until now we have spoken of co-operative movements, but this must be explained. There is no question here of mitigated co-operation which could become, by degrees, a real co-operative. The Indians do not possess an exact notion of co-operation. They need a chief (Brother Ménard) who, by degrees, will make them understand all that is expected from them by the co-operative. The sum of $25.00, as share, will be asked from each member, in one lump sum or by instalments. This will be a means of uniting them more closely, and the sum received, including the $150.00 presently in our reserve, will constitute the initial necessary capital of the society towards its activities.
In all the said activities, the members employed will be paid salaries. Out of the receipts, a dividend will be paid at the pro-rata of the number of hours of work, and another dividend will be paid at the pro-rata of shares; it is understood that Brother Ménard will receive no compensation. However, as the Indians lack perseverance, we wish that a certain part of the receipts be set aside in the name of the society, which will make up the capital required to pay the wages or the purchases which the society will necessarily have to make. It is because of that that we will say that we can only at the present time indulge into mitigated co-operation. The co-operative promises to give detailed reports either to the Government or to the Agent, according to their wish.

Exceptional opportunities.

We recognize that this is an exceptional opportunity to try the experience of a co-operative society among the Indians. Indeed, Cross Lake is the only school in the Vicariate where favourable conditions presently exist to do something for the Indians.

Kindly reply as soon as possible in order that we may know your point of view in regard to the points mentioned in our letter.

Yours truly,

Martin Lajeunesse, Q.M.
Vicar Apostolic of Keewatin.

With further reference to correspondence herein, we are in receipt of a letter from Rev. Father Trudeau, Cross Lake, which reads, in part, as follows:

"I am just in receipt of yours of December the 15th, Re: Rototiller that was shipped to us last June. When I received it I also received the Invoices and a letter from the Dept. of Mines and Natural Resources asking me to receipt the Invoices only when I will have received all the attachments. By the first mail of the Winter I received another letter of the Dept. asking me to receipt the Invoices, so I did it and sent them to Ottawa in the first week of December. So I hope you have been paid off now. As you see, the delay was not due to Agency from my part but I was just following the instructions I had received from the Dept. of Mines & Resources.

As you have now in stock the planter and seeder would you please send it to C.M.R. Station, Wabowden, Man., where I could get it during the winter as it is our nearest railway station. I would also like to get the furrower."

In accordance with Father Trudeau's instructions, we despatched to him on January 7th, the planter and seeder attachment, but not the furrower, as we have none in stock at present. As already advised, as soon as a shipment comes in we will despatch one to him at once.

December 3, 1948.

Department of Mines and Natural Resources,
Ottawa,
Ontario.

Attention Mr. W.M. Vincent,
Purchasing Agent.

Dear Sir,

We have your letter of November 30, and note you are unable to trace the charge of $23.40, as per our statement mailed to you at the end of October.

In order to give you a clear picture of the account, we enclose herewith a complete statement of same, together with copies of invoices showing how the items were shipped to Rev. Father Trudeau at Cross Lake Indian Mission.

The reason there may be some confusion in your mind about this account is that on January 6, 1948, Father Trudeau ordered Rototiller parts and accessories in the amount of $44.60, and requested us to bill your department for same. On January 12, we received your cheque for $25.00, leaving balance due of $109.40. Your reason for not settling the full amount of $258.96 was because you had not shipped the planter and furrower to Father Trudeau along with the Rototiller and some other attachments, as per your letter of February 19, in which you stated you would not pay for these items until they were received at Cross Lake. However, on March we received payment of the parts account from Father Trudeau, which amount we credited to your account in the sum of $44.60, leaving the balance due us of $64.80. On February 26, we received a further payment from you of $41.40, leaving the balance due us of $23.40.

Yours very truly,

(Mrs.) E.M. Millidge
Secretary-Treasurer

M.

Poplar River, Man.,
Via Burne River,
Nov. 19, 1942.

Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir;

Previously the Indian Day School received the sum of $7.00 for janitor work. It is absolutely necessary that this sum be paid again. I am unable to do the janitor work, as I have too many other duties to perform. I must preach, teach school, dispense medicines, keep vital statistics records, visit the sick, dispense relief rations and do the necessary buying and chores. My wife performs the schoolwork.

The Indians refuse to do any work unless they get cash.

In the agreement that I signed with the Department I was hired to teach school. Janitor work was not mentioned. Janitor work is not my duty. I have been forced to do it since school started and I expect to get paid for it. In the future the work must be done by someone else. I have written to Mr. McPherson, Selkirk, Man., but have received no reply.

Yours Truly,

Edward Shankle, D.A.
Ottawa,
December 8, 1942.

Deulon, Man.,
Oct. 12, 1944

Mr. R.A. Hey,
Superintendent of Indian Affairs Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find a letter from Mr. W.S. Pelton in reply to my having not received the April, May, and June janitor fees for the Fort Alexander Day School.

To date the $7 have not been received. I should be very grateful if you would please have same forwarded to the above address.

I had an Indian do the janitor work for the winter, but I did the first the last quarter.

Looking forward to a reply.

Yours truly,

Gladys E. Cline.
Selkirk, July 25/44

Dear Mrs Cline:

Regarding your Janitor fees for the June 1st, these come direct from the Dept and no doubt you will receive same soon.

I am sorry to inform you that you will have to be out of the house by Aug. 1st as we are expecting to have the house redecorated.

Yours truly,

E. McPherson,
Indian Agent

Mrs G. Cline,
Pine Falls, Man.

Ottawa, October 16, 1944.

Dear Mrs. Cline:

In reply to your letter of the 12th instant, I wish to advise that janitor fees for the Fort Alexander Indian Day School, amounting to $5.00 for the June Quarter were paid under Cheque No. 70452 and was mailed October 4th addressed to you at Pine Falls, Manitoba.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mrs. G. Cline,
Teulon, Manitoba.

Dear Sir,

March 31, 1947

I reported 2 months ago I want to leave my work at the school and I didn't get answer yet Mr. Garcelle was here today and he told me to write to you about this and kindly let me know at what time as the man has ready then the one his going to take the job. So hope to hear from you soon as possible.

Yours Truly,

Alex Bruce
Portage la Prairie
Manitoba.

April 5, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to enclose herewith a letter received from Alex Bruce, Caretaker, Fairford Improved Day School, in which he resigns his position as caretaker as from March 31st.

Farm Instructor Favelle writes that Charles Marsden, 117 Fairford Band, is willing to undertake this work and I beg to recommend his appointment be approved. This Indian is reliable and should fit into the work of caretaker. He also lives close to the school.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
April 8, 1943.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.

With reference to your letter of the 5th instant, the Department accepts the resignation of Alex Bruce, caretaker of the Fairford Day School, effective March 31, 1943. We also approve the appointment of Charles Marsden as caretaker of this school, effective April 1, 1943, at a salary of $20.00 a teaching month.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

November 24, 1943.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to advise that the caretaking of the schools, Fairford Reserve, is being done by Francis Hall No. 145 Fairford land. The cost previously allowed by the Department was $20.00 per month. Hall is asking that $25.00 be allowed for this work. The work consists of lighting the fires in the morning at both schools, which are 1½ miles apart, sweeping the floors after school hours, scrubbing the floors every two weeks, setting in sufficient wood and water for the day. The work takes up the greater part of the day and leaves the caretaker little time for other work of a remunerative character. Hall is doing satisfactory work, is not particularly well, and is the only Indian on the reserve who will do this work. The other Indians can make more money at other work and will not consider the caretaking job under the present prosperous conditions. Hall requests an additional $5 for the months of September and October and $25 per month for November and future months.

The allowance is no doubt very small under present conditions and I would recommend that the Indian be allowed his requests. I am certain that no other Indian on the reserve would do the work for the amount Hall is asking.

Will you please advise in this matter as soon as possible as it is Hall's intention to quit if his wage is not raised.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
November 27, 1943.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 24th instant, the Department will allow a total of $25.00 a month to Francois Hall for the janitor work at the two Fairford schools.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
